We the undersigned citizens of Australia, believing
that Australia should not host nuclear weapons in its territory or in Australian waters; and
that the presence of nuclear-armed warships makes a priority nuclear target of ports being visited; and

DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Powell) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1986.
Bill presented by Senator Powell, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

As honourable senators will recall, the Act to be amended by this Bill was passed by the Senate on 22nd August this year. During debate on the Bill, Senator Haines identified several deficiencies in its contents and the Australian Democrats had a series of amendments designed to remedy these and strengthen the legislation overall.

Unfortunately, as that was the last day of that sitting, to have proceeded with the amendments then would have delayed passage of the Bill and the implementation of the significant reforms contained in it. Senator Haines quite rightly pointed out that getting the legislation into operation as quickly as possible was most important, and it was extremely regrettable that government business had been handled in such a way that time constraints prevented the amendments being dealt with at the time.

The Government's mismanagement of this situation was matched by the attitude of the Opposition. It was quite extraordinary to read that Senator Chaney protested vehemently about the extended sitting time to deal with the affirmative action legislation. He did not think, he said, that there would be very many people in Australia who would regard the extension of parliamentary sitting hours to Friday night as being necessary in that particular cause-that is, the affirmative action legislation. Senator Chaney went on to say that if the Senate were dealing with rising interest rates, or the fall in private investment, for example, there might have been some virtue in it. The legislation being given priority, the significant and long-delayed affirmative action legislation was, Senator Chaney assured the Senate, peripheral to the central concerns of most Australians. I would suggest to Senator Chaney that the women of Australia and those men who believe in equitable treatment for all people, would take a rather different view. Certainly the Democrats did not share Senator Chaney's opinion.
It remains true, however, that the Act is defective in that it does not go far enough and this Bill deals with its outstanding shortcomings.

As I indicated earlier, the Democrats are concerned to strengthen the Act. The women of Australia have waited a long time for affirmative action legislation and there is an obligation on this Parliament to ensure that the legislation takes the best possible form. The Government and the Opposition could have no argument with the amendments proposed in this Bill if their commitment to affirmative action is as strong as they would have us believe in their rhetoric.

The first amendment deals with the companies which took part in the affirmative action pilot program. Section 7 of the principal Act sets out the timing for development and implementation of affirmative action programs for relevant employers. There are different operative dates for relevant employers in different categories, but we believe that the companies which took part in the pilot program should be required to commence the development of their programs at the first stage of implementation. Whichever of the categories these companies fall into, the experience of the pilot program should have readied them for implementation.

No doubt it will be suggested that this disadvantages the companies concerned, that other companies in the same category would have longer to prepare themselves. This is nonsense, of course, because the groundwork has been laid by participation in the pilot program and no disadvantage would be suffered.

The second amendment in this Bill is adding to the powers and functions of the Director of Affirmative Action. It makes provision for the provision and development of special programs to meet the particular needs of women of Aboriginal descent, women from non-English speaking backgrounds and disabled women. It is beyond my comprehension why this has not been provided for in the principal Act. Certainly it is beyond dispute that these three groups of women are particularly disadvantaged and it is therefore even more imperative that their needs are pinpointed in the Act. At the time the Act was debated it seemed unlikely that either the Government or the Opposition would support this Amendment. I hope that they have thought again about the issue, but if not, these three groups of women would be very interested to hear the reasons for opposing the amendment. Quite simply, there are no reasons for opposing it, but any flimsy excuses offered for doing so would make fascinating reading. Let us hope for the sake of these particularly disadvantaged groups of women that the outcome will be positive.

The amendment to section 13 of the principal Act provides, in effect, for more detailed reporting than is required at present. As honourable senators are aware, the affirmative action program provided for in the Act has eight steps. The Australian Democrats believe that each of these eight steps should be reported upon in the reports to be lodged with the Director of Affirmative Action. Again, it is difficult to see any arguments against this amendment. The major parties support the legislation and presumably believe that the eight step program is worthwhile. It is surely just as worthwhile to have separate reports on each of these steps. The additional information would be invaluable and would assist in future development of the program. I fear that in this instance, too, support will not be forthcoming from the Government and Opposition and their reasons will have no more substance than those they have advanced in opposing other improvements of the Act.

The amendment to section 14 is designed to exclude higher education institutions from being able to make confidential reports. The provision for confidential reporting is clearly necessary where commercial considerations apply-as they do with some employers covered by the Act. But this is not the case with higher education institutions and such institutions should, therefore, submit public reports on their affirmative action programs. In addition, of course, these institutions are funded by public money and this adds further strength to the argument in favour of public reporting.

The insertion of section 14a in the principal Act makes provision for separate reports by subsidiaries. It is obviously desirable that the Act be absolutely clear about the possibility of subsidiary corporations reporting separately. There are numerous conglomerates throughout Australia where each subsidiary would qualify independently under the Act. This amendment would not require the reporting to be done one way or the other-that is, by either the conglomerate or by each of the subsidiaries-but enables it to be done either way. A different approach will be appropriate in different circumstances and the amendment makes allowance for this.

The amendment to section 18 addresses a concern raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The section deals with requests for further information, and, as it stands, no minimum period is stipulated nor is it requested that the period specified be reasonable. The Democrat amendment adopts the latter solution and we share the Committee's concern that the section was drafted without providing for this.

The section 19 amendments are very important. Employers who fail to meet their forward estimates without reasonable excuse ought to be named by the Director of Affirmative Action in the report to be tabled in Parliament. The insertion of this amendment will remedy one of the significant weaknesses in the Act. Similarly, the other amendment to section 19 strengthens the Act in a significant way. As it stands, the Act contains no sanctions other than the possibility of a relevant employer being named in the Director's report. At the very least, the naming of employers who fail to submit reports as required by legislation should be mandatory and the amendment alters the section accordingly. The naming in Parliament of all employers who fall short of the expectations of the legislation must occur if the Act is to be taken seriously.

The final amendment, while leaving the matter to the discretion of the Minister, ensures that regard will be had to the extent of compliance with the Affirmative Action Act in relation to financial assistance to higher education institutions. By making this provision, the Act is strengthened and a further incentive to comply is included.

With all these amendments, as I said before, the Australian Democrats are seeking to improve a most important piece of legislation. We have always expressed our support for the principles embodied in the Affirmative Action Act, and the Act in the form it passed was a step in the right direction. We now have the opportunity to make it even better. I hope the major parties' opposition to these amendments has disappeared on calmer reflection. There are no arguments of any substance that could be mounted against them and they undoubtedly strengthen various aspects of the affirmative action programs. I urge honourable senators to consider the implications for the women of Australia and to vote for the amendments accordingly.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill I am introducing today is to amend the Freedom of Information Act 1982 and the Freedom of Information (Charges) Regulations to reduce administrative costs and increase revenues. The main points are:
Introduction of application fees for requests for access to documents and for internal review of decisions;
to increase the hourly charge for search and retrieval of documents;
to introduce an hourly charge for decision-making time;
to exempt persons seeking personal income maintenance documents from all charges and fees;
to maintain after 1 December 1986 the present 45-day time limit for processing requests;
to strengthen provisions for refusal of requests on work load grounds;
to reduce the grounds for remission of charges;
to reduce the obligations on agencies to publish section 8 and section 9 statements and to report statistics; and
miscellaneous amendments of a minor nature.
Background

As was clear from the introduction of this Bill in the House of Representatives on Budget night, the Government continues to be gravely concerned by the costs of operation and administration of the Freedom of Information Act and by the very low contribution made by users towards meeting those costs.

Honourable senators will recollect that in June 1985 the Government issued new directions designed to maximise disclosure of information whilst reducing the costs of administering the Freedom of Information Act. Administrative aspects of those measures, particularly the clearance role of the Attorney-General's Department, have been valuable in reducing the number of disputes about release of information. Furthermore, costs of processing requests have continued to decrease as agencies gain experience and improve procedures. However, the other major aspect of the Government's directions-changes to the charges regulations designed to simplify charging procedures and recoup a more significant contribution by users of the legislation-was frustrated when the amendments were disallowed by the Senate on 13 November 1985.

In 1984-85 the operation and administration of the FOI Act cost the Commonwealth between $16m and $19m, depending on the precise allowance made for overheads, and the preliminary figures for 1985-86 indicate a cost between $14m and $16m. Although there is some indication that the total number of requests is levelling off-preliminary estimates for 1985-86 are 36,000 to 37,000 requests as against 33,000 in 1984-85-it is clear that administration of the Act will continue to involve very substantial Commonwealth expenditure.

It is also clear that under the present charging structure only very small contributions will be received from users of the legislation-about $22,000 in 1984-85 and perhaps $60,000 in 1985-86-or rather less than half a per cent of the administrative costs.
Australia simply cannot afford such a situation. The problems identified by the Government in June 1985 remain. Ways must be found to reduce costs and encourage efficient use of the Act.

Economic circumstances are such that the Government must take action now. In recent months an inter-departmental committee has been examining options for FOI costs savings. This Bill draws on the work of that committee, though there will doubtless be further possibilities for longer term consideration when it reports.

The operation and administration of the FOI Act is also currently under review by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That wide-ranging review will doubtless encompass costs questions.

Whilst the urgency of the current economic situation requires Government action now, this does not preclude further consideration of the issues in the light of the reports of the inter-departmental committee and the Senate Standing Committee.
I shall briefly describe the main features of this Bill. Further details may be obtained from the explanatory memorandum.
Application Fees

The Bill proposes a $30 application fee for all requests. This will cover the cost of basic administrative procedures involved in processing the request. The existing $8 charge in respect of administrative procedures will be subsumed in this fee. It will be necessary to pay the fee when making a request. Until the fee is paid there will be no obligation on the agency to deal with the request.
Processing Charges

The existing charge of $12 per hour in respect of time spent searching for and retrieving documents is to be increased to $15 per hour. This increase takes some account of increases in wages and other costs since the charge was set in 1982.

Where requested documents cover sensitive areas such as security, law enforcement, business, policy development and the like, it is often necessary for agencies to consult widely about possible implications of disclosure and to give very careful consideration to the consequences. This can be a costly process which must often be carried out by senior officers. It has accordingly been decided to introduce a new charge of $20 per hour in respect of the time spent determining what access can be granted to a document.
Internal Reviews

Whilst internal review is certainly less costly than review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and is therefore a desirable intermediate stage, there is nothing in the existing charges structure to encourage an applicant to first consider whether he has been properly treated by the agency. He can always hope that review will result in release of more material, or in other favourable action, at no cost to himself. It is accordingly proposed that there be a $40 application fee for internal review of agency decisions.
Personal Income Maintenance Documents

No fees or charges will be payable by persons seeking access to their own personal income maintenance documents. The only exception will be where the person has already had access during the preceding three months and there has been no material change to the documents concerned.
Remission

The existing provision for remission of charges provides that account must be taken of whether a request relates to a person's personal affairs, whether payments would cause hardship and whether disclosure of the documents is in the public interest. The last criterion has caused particular administrative difficulty. In practice many claims for remission on public interest grounds have been generated by members of Parliament who have other effective means of access to Government information or by media organisations operating on a commercial basis which are well able to make some contribution towards meeting the costs of processing their requests. It is proposed to remove this as a mandatory consideration in considering remission of charges.

The existing remission provisions are not procedurally suited to dealing with remission of the new application fees. A new section will permit remission of an application fee on the limited grounds that payment would cause financial hardship and that the documents relate to the applicant's personal affairs.
45-Day Time Limit

As the Act stands at present the time limit for responding to requests would reduce to 30 days from 1 December 1986. Meeting this reduced time limit would require extra agency staff. It is proposed to maintain the present 45-day time limit.
Refusal on Work Load Grounds

Some requests have absorbed very large resources, adding up to many staff months or even staff years. Three difficulties have been encountered in applying the existing provisions in this Act enabling refusal of requests on work load grounds:
First, only large requests directed towards classes of documents can be refused. Requests for large numbers of individually specified documents cannot be refused;
Secondly, there is no simple test of what constitutes an unreasonable work load;
Thirdly, the tests take account only of time spent searching for and retrieving documents but not, generally speaking, time spent in consultation and deliberation regarding exempt content.
The first difficulty will be met by extending the exemption to cover requests for large numbers of identified documents.

As for the second difficulty, whilst it would seem to involved a substantial diversion of resources in a large Department to spend, say, more than 5 full staff days processing a single request, such a diversion of resources could totally disrupt a small agency or office, particularly if it arose when staff were heavily pressed by other commitments. It is not therefore at this stage proposed to introduce an absolute limit on workload.

The test will simply be whether the likely total work in dealing with the request would substantially divert the resources of the agency from its other operations; would interfere substantially with the performance by the Minister of the Minister's functions; or would result in substantial delays in dealing with other requests.
The last point has been introduced as it would seen quite unfair that one person who made a large request should be able to hinder access to Government information by other persons.

The third difficulty will be met by providing that the total work shall be estimated having regard not only to the location and retrieval of relevant documents but also to the consultation and deliberation involved in deciding upon exempt matter.
Publication of Information on Agencies

At present agencies are required to separately publish statements concerning their organisation and functions. This results in significant duplication of material normally included in agency annual reports. The Bill proposes that the publications be amalgamated.

The Act also requires publication in the Gazette of an index of manuals, guidelines and other internal documents used by agencies in decision-making. There has been little evidence of public demand for such materials sufficient to justify printing and publication in bulk. The Bill proposes that copies of the index be available for inspection and purchase at the information access offices already established. This `publication on demand' will avoid printing and publication costs without diminishing public access to the information.
Agency Statistics

The Attorney-General is currently required to report annually to Parliament on the operation of the FOI Act. A wide range of statistical information must be provided to my Department by agencies for this purpose at considerable cost. It is proposed to very much simplify this statistical information which must be reported. The Bill proposes a reduction to the minimum considered necessary for monitoring the general operation of the Act.
Miscellaneous Amendments

Apart from minor amendments consequential on the major changes described above, the Bill makes an amendment of section 45 to ensure that material provided in confidence to government by non-government sources will be protected even where the information has been incorporated in internal working documents.

As the Health Insurance Commission now has certain functions in relation to investigation of Medicare fraud and overservicing it is no longer appropriate that the Commission should be totally exempt from the operation of the Act. Its transfer from Part I to Part II of the Schedule will provide that it is exempt only in relation to documents concerning its competitive commercial activities.
Application
The new fees and charges in the Bill will take effect only in respect of future applications and requests.
Conclusions

It is estimated that total revenue to be derived from the above measures will be about $4m per year. Additionally, the measures in relation to publication, statistics and burdensome requests will result in cost savings of about $4m. Together, the measures will reduce the net cost of the FOI Act by about $8m or 50 per cent. This is a significant contribution towards meeting the Government's budgetary objectives.
Honourable senators will note that these savings do not result from significantly reduced rights of access.

The express exemption from fees and charges of persons seeking access to personal income maintenance documents will protect those who are most vulnerable in respect of access to information they need. The remission provisions will continue to protect other persons where hardship might otherwise prevent access to personal documents. In other cases requesters will make a contribution towards the costs of providing the benefits they receive. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN LAND TRANSPORT (FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Act 1985 to give effect to the announcements made by the Government on 12 June 1986. It adjusts the rate of duty and excise on petrol and diesel which is hypothecated to the Australian Land Transport Program Trust Fund. This measure, and the decision to hold payments in 1986/87 under the Australian bicentennial road development program and ALTP to $1,250m, form an integral part of the Government's overall economic strategy.

The Bill will reduce the rate of duty hypothecated to the trust fund by 0.235c per litre from 1 July 1986. It also authorises the repayment from the ALTP Trust Fund to the Consolidated Revenue Fund of the revenue generated in the period from 1 July 1986 by the 0.235c per litre adjustment, taking into account subsequent indexation adjustments and any interest earned by these funds while they are retained in the trust fund.

These amendments do not alter the Government's fundamental commitment to developing a better road system for Australia. This Government-more than any of its predecessors-has highlighted the need for a road system which serves the interests of the Australian community, including our industries. We have recognised that roads facilitate the interaction of commerce between our major cities, between communities and within communities. We are bringing all Australians closer together.

Road transport is a fundamental part of the Australian way of life. Well designed and constructed roads make significant contributions to Australia. They reduce costs. They save lives. They encourage all forms of industry. They repay to Australia far more than their cost. However, in the current economic circumstances where Australia is under pressure from external factors it is essential that each sector of the economy and the community makes a contribution towards the overall well-being of the country. The downwards adjustment and the excise rate proposed will reduce payments to the Trust Fund by about $50m a year from that originally projected for 1986/87.

Turning to details of the Bill, clauses 1 and 2 contain the usual citation and commencement provisions. Clause 3 of the Bill provides for the rate of excise payable to the ALTP Trust Fund to be 3.610c per litre from 1 July 1986 by the insertion of section 14a into the principal Act. This varies by 0.235c per litre the rate which would otherwise have applied from 1 July. Clause 4 of the Bill makes a minor adjustment to the wording of section 15 (7) of the Principal Act.

Clause 5 of the Bill provides for the revenue generated by the 0.235c per litre adjustment to be paid out of the ALTP Trust Fund to the Consolidated Revenue Fund. In accordance with the established indexing procedure for the rate of duty of excise on motor spirit and diesel fuel under ALTP, this variation of 0.235c will also be indexed with the associated revenue to be paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund in due course. Clause 5 also provides for any investment income which may accrue to these moneys whilst they are held in the ALTP Trust Fund to likewise be paid to Consolidated Revenue. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Bill before the Senate makes a number of important changes to areas within the health portfolio. Most of these changes have already been announced by the Government as part of the Budget and are, in the main, measures which will provide substantial reductions in government expenditure. Honourable senators are aware of the difficult economic circumstances which necessitated a rigorous scrutiny of all areas of government expenditure. Clearly the health portfolio had to play its part, but the Government was concerned to ensure that any changes should be made in the fairest possible way.

The amendments in this Bill are part of an overall package of measures within the health area which achieves the Government's Budget objective of restraint with equity. In relation to Medicare the Bill will increase the maximum gap payment between the Medicare rebate and the schedule of fees from $10 to $20 from 1 November. Complementary changes not requiring legislative amendments are the deferral of schedule fee increases until 1 November and the 25 per cent reduction in schedule fees for 18 pathology tests, which has applied since 1 August.

These changes, together with the increase in the Medicare levy to 1.25 per cent, have enabled the Government to preserve its commitment to a universal health insurance scheme based on the principles of equity, simplicity and cost efficiency. Importantly, by adopting this particular strategy, the Government has been able to maintain the Medicare rebate at 85 per cent of the schedule fee thereby ensuring the continuation of bulk billing which overwhelmingly works to the benefit of pensioners and the disadvantaged. Since 1 July this year nearly 52 per cent of all medical services under Medicare have been direct billed and the vast majority of these were for services provided to pensioners and the disadvantaged. In addition, the maintenance of an income related levy ensures that the burden of paying for health care is spread across the whole community on the basis of ability to pay rather than simply on the sick.

Other major amendments included in this Bill are the establishment of a new pharmaceutical benefits scheme which will provide assistance to those with chronic illnesses and other high volume users of prescription drugs. The isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme is to be abolished from 1 January 1987, although the Commonwealth will continue to fund replacement arrangements administered by the States. Commonwealth controls over the approval and categorisation of private hospitals are to be removed. This latter change accompanies the announcement in the Budget that Commonwealth subsidies to private hospitals will cease from 1 October 1986.

I turn now to more detailed explanation of the major features of this Bill. Clause 5 of the Bill provides for an increase in the maximum patient contribution between the Medicare benefit rebate and the schedule of fees from $10 to $20 to take effect from 1 November 1986. This is the first increase in this gap since it was introduced in 1978. The increase takes into account the effects of inflation over the past eight years. However, the change will only effect those Medicare services costing more than $67. Therefore the increase will not affect the vast majority of items involving consultations, which are by far the most common type of services.

While the maximum gap payment will increase, the Government will continue to maintain safeguards for people faced with substantial out-of-pocket expenses for medical services. The $150 maximum annual total gap between benefits and schedule fees will be maintained, which means that once the ceiling of $150 has been reached Medicare benefits are payable at 100 per cent of schedule fee levels. Private patients in hospitals will continue to have gap payments for medical services covered by their private hospital insurance organisations. In addition, as I have already noted, the Government has retained the 85 per cent rebate level which will enable practitioners to continue to direct bill for pensioners and the chronically ill.

Clause 7 of the Bill repeals provisions in the Health Insurance Act dealing with the approval and categorisation of private hospitals. These amendments will deregulate controls over private hospitals. An associated measure, also announced by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech, is the removal of Government subsidies to private hospitals from 1 October 1986. As a result of this measure private health insurers will incur additional benefit liability but it is not expected to significantly impact on contribution rates. The exact increases in contribution rates will vary from fund to fund and State to State but, as most funds have accumulated significant levels of reserves, increases should be moderate.

Mr President, deregulation of private hospitals is part of the Government's overall strategy of streamlining government and assisting the private sector by removing overlapping and unnecessary layers of bureaucracy. De- regulation also fulfils the undertaking given by the Government to the Australian Medical Association in April 1985, as part of the settlement package for the New South Wales doctors' dispute. The Government has long held the view that the regulation of private hospitals is more appropriately a State responsibility. Only the States have the detailed knowledge required for the rational planning and provision of both public and private hospital services. On the other hand the appropriate role for the Commonwealth is to develop national health policy objectives-not the detailed administration of controls that the States should be administering.

The devolution to the States of Commonwealth controls over the approval and categorisation of private hospital accommodation was an integral part of the original Medicare proposals and is a logical corollary to withdrawal of the subsidy. These controls, while required to prevent unnecessary Commonwealth expenditure, in practice, duplicated State controls. The associated abolition of the present government subsidy will not mean a loss of revenue for private hospitals because basic table fund benefits will be increased by the amount of the subsidy-indeed, hospitals will save in administrative costs by removal of the Commonwealth from the claims and payment process.

At the request of the industry the current system of paying hospital fund benefits according to the categorisation of private hospitals will be continued as an administrative arrangement for an interim period pending introduction of revised patient classification arrangements from March 1987. As from 1 October 1986 the Minister for Health will declare a new basic hospital table which will ensure that each private hospital receives benefits for insured patients at least equivalent to the sum of the fund benefits and Commonwealth bed day subsidy that were applicable to patients of that hospital on 30 September 1986. In addition the Bill provides for continuation of applications and cases before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal commenced before 1 October, if this is the wish of the applicants.

As a transitional arrangement, the Commonwealth will consider assisting certain private charitable, religious and community hospitals which historically have cared for needy uninsured patients and whose viability has been reliant on the subsidy. The assistance will be in the form of specific purpose lump sum grants to eligible hospitals for the remainder of this financial year. Longer term considerations for these hospitals will be discussed between the Commonwealth and the States. To be eligible, hospitals will have to demonstrate that they have a history of caring for uninsured patients and that a grant to maintain financial viability is necessary to enable continuation of existing services.

While dealing with the amendments that the Bill makes to the Health Insurance Act, I would refer honourable senators to two minor but important changes. Sub-clause 4(3), which amends the definition of `prescribed dental patient', will enable the Minister, by determination, to extend Medicare cover of the cleft lip and palate scheme, to include children with other facial deformities as was originally intended by the scheme.

Clause 9 of the Bill amends the secrecy provisions of the Health Insurance Act to further limit the permissible disclosure of information under the exceptions to this provision. In its 79th report, the Senate committee on regulations and ordinances raised some concerns about certain possible disclosures of information and this amendment is designed to meet the committee's concerns.

Part III of the Bill contains amendments to the National Health Act 1953. The amendment made by clause 15 is included to enable the Government to proceed with its proposal to introduce a new program designed to reduce the incidence of hepatitis B among new-born babies most at risk of contracting the disease. This is achieved by including in section 9B of the Act a capacity to expand by regulation the list of diseases for which vaccines may be provided. This approach has the advantage of enabling a quick response to future needs.

I turn now to clause 16 of the Bill which repeals the provisions of the Act establishing the isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme-IPTAAS. As previously announced, this repeal is intended to take effect from 1 January 1987, although the Bill preserves the rights of patients who have commenced journeys to seek medical treatment before that date.

As in the case of private hospital deregulation, the abolition of IPTAAS represents a rational streamlining of an inappropriate Commonwealth activity and therefore should be welcomed by all honourable senators. Indeed, as many of the criticisms of the current IPTAAS arrangement have come from honourable senators opposite, I would be very surprised if the abolition of the scheme in favour of funding to the States does not receive bipartisan support.

In the second reading debate on the introduction of IPTAAS in the other place, my colleague Dr Blewett expressed concern about the monstrously bureaucratic arrangements associated with the administration of the scheme. Unfortunately that concern has proven to be fully justified. Since becoming Minister for Health, Dr Blewett has received numerous representations which, whilst supporting the basic principles and objectives of the scheme, have nevertheless criticised many of its aspects. The criticisms have come from a wide range of sources including State Ministers for Health, Federal and State members, the Commonwealth Ombudsman, groups representing specific classes of patients, groups representing rural patients, social workers associations and individual patients. The scheme has also been criticised by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The States and Territories are, of course, responsible for the planning and provision of health services and for the actual provision of specific patient transport services such as land and air ambulances and inter-hospital transfers. In super-imposing IPTAAS the Commonwealth inappropriately stepped into an area of State and Territory responsibility and effectively distanced the States from valuable planning information on the effectiveness and distribution of their own services. Moreover, the Commonwealth is poorly placed to administer any scheme of this nature, having no suitable delivery and processing mechanism outside of the capital cities and at best only a second-hand knowledge of available services. On the other hand State hospital and welfare delivery networks are well established and some already provide cash advances to the needy in anticipation of IPTAAS benefits. Accordingly the States and Territories are well placed to develop and administer more flexible and effective measures for those in need.

In deciding to abolish IPTAAS, the Government was particularly conscious that, despite its faults, the program has provided a tremendous amount of much needed support to patients in rural and isolated areas and that the needs of those people must be protected. Accordingly the Commonwealth will continue to provide substantial funding for patient transport assistance. Funds for the States and the Northern Territory will be provided through special revenue assistance grants. On a full year basis this funding represents a 26 per cent increase over IPTAAS benefits paid in 1985-86 and the funds will be distributed among the States and Territories in proportion to the actual distribution of IPTAAS benefits in that year.

This generous increase in funding will be more than sufficient for the States and Territories to provide effective patient transport arrangements or to provide a greater frequency and range of specialist services to people in remote areas. It will also enable them to meet any demands that might arise for inter-state transport, including from capital city residents, for highly specialised services such as liver and heart transplants, magnetic resonance imaging and lithotripsy. I emphasise however, that the new arrangements are a matter for each State and Territory to determine, having regard to its own distribution of specialist services and the specific needs of its rural population.

On 1 September last year, benefits were introduced to the basic hospital insurance table for day surgery and for the cost of surgically implanted prostheses in public and private hospitals. Sub-clause 14(1) of the Bill extends these benefits to apply to prostheses supplied in approved free-standing day surgery facilities. There are now five such facilities in Australia. I believe that the continued development of new surgical and anaesthetic techniques will enable many more surgical procedures to be safely completed without the need for an overnight stay, greatly reducing hospital costs and disruption to patients. I take this opportunity to endorse the work of the pioneers of day surgery in established hospitals and new specialised facilities, and hope that the health insurance industry will recognise the potential savings by offering greater cover on their supplementary tables to further encourage this development.

The next major changes made by the Bill concern pharmaceutical benefits. Clause 21 of the Bill provides for an increase in the maximum general and concessional patient contributions for pharmaceutical benefits. These changes will be effective from 1 November 1986. General patients will pay a variable amount up to a maximum of $10 per prescription for the supply of a pharmaceutical benefit. Whilst the maximum a patient will pay is $10, the Government estimates the average patient contribution will be about $7.30.

The concessional patient contribution will increase from $2 to $2.50. This will be the first increase in the contribution since its introduction on 1 January 1983 and is broadly in line with movements in prices and incomes since then. As in the past, pensioners holding a pensioner health benefits card and their dependants, and sickness beneficiaries holding a health benefits card and their dependants, will not be charged for pharmaceutical benefits. In those few cases where a special patient contribution applies, patients will continue to pay that special patient contribution as well as the standard charge, if applicable. This also applies to pensioners.

From 1 November 1986 pharmaceutical benefits for war widows and their dependants will not be available through the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Instead, pharmaceutical benefits will be available to these persons free of charge through the pensioner pharmaceutical benefits scheme. This change will result in improved efficiency of administration.

A major feature of the amendments is to incorporate a safety net which will apply to the supply of pharmaceutical benefits to general and concessional patients. The amendments provide that, from 1 November 1986, no individual or family, including concessional beneficiaries, will have to pay for more than 25 pharmaceutical benefits scheme prescription items in any calender year. In the first instance the `safety net' will run for 14 months, from 1 November 1986 to 31 December 1987. After that, the scheme will apply for each calendar year.

After 1 November 1986, individuals or families will be able to obtain a prescription record form from their pharmacist. This is provided for in clause 19. The pharmacist will enter on the form a record of each prescription supplied. After 25 entries, the pharmacist will issue the individual or family with a pharmaceutical benefits entitlement card which will allow them to receive free pharmaceutical benefits for the remainder of the entitlement period. It is not anticipated that the administrative work load on individual pharmacists will be significant and agreement has been reached with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia on payments to pharmacists for issuing pharmaceutical benefits entitlement cards.

I point out to honourable senators that this scheme has been developed with the full co-operation of the Pharmpay Guild of Australia. Indeed, the Guild's assistance has made the task that much easier and I would like to place on record my appreciation of the valuable contribution made by the Guild in the development of this new pharmaceutical benefits scheme. In addition, the Department of Health and the Guild will continue to monitor the impact of the new scheme upon the community to maximise its effectiveness and ensure that there are no abuses of the new arrangements. Clearly the Government had to rein in costs during a time of economic restraint, but in doing so we have been able to increase protection for high volume users of pharmaceutical benefits scheme drugs. I believe this is a long overdue reform and one which should have the support of both sides of the Senate.

I also remind honourable senators that, as part of the Government's changes to assist those with chronic illnesses, arrangements have been made to pay an annual grant to the Australian Diabetes Foundation to provide diabetics with essential supplies including insulin syringes and needles. This is an important element of our chronic protection plan and one which has been welcomed by the diabetes organisations.

Part IV of the Bill contains amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1966. That Act was amended in 1981 to introduce a batch release system for biological therapeutic goods, such as vaccines, so as to enable the quality of products to be assessed before release to the public. Clauses 41 and 42 of the Bill insert new sections 23da and 23ea into the Therapeutic Goods Act. These are machinery amendments intended to correct legal inadequacies in the earlier provisions. Under the new provisions the Secretary of the Department of Health will be empowered to obtain specific information from a manufacturer, and to have official tests performed on samples, before a specific batch can be released for use. The amendments will ensure that the batch release system provides an effective mechanism of preventing the marketing of unsafe or ineffective biological products.

Clause 44 of the Bill inserts into the Therapeutic Goods Act a new regulation-making power to provide, amongst other things, for the inspection of manufacturing companies' operations and procedures which will ensure the Australian public is supplied with therapeutic goods that meet quality, safety and efficacy requirements. The Bill also contains a number of minor and drafting amendments.
Financial Impact Statement

The increase in maximum patient contribution payable for Medicare services from $10 to $20 will result in savings of $18m in 1986-87-with introduction from 1 November 1986-and $29m in a full year. The increase in patient contributions for pharmaceutical benefits, together with the introduction of the `safety net' measures, is expected to reduce government pharmaceutical benefits scheme expenditure by approximately $56.6m in 1986-87 and approximately $67m in 1987-88.

The abolition of the isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme and the provision of alternative funding to the States and Territories will result in a total Commonwealth expenditure of $24.2m for patient transport assistance in 1986-87. The sum of $13.3m will be provided for the remaining life of IPTAAS and takes into account the backlog of claims and the lag in submitting claims after the abolition. The sum of $10.9m will be provided to the States and Territories for the first 6 months of 1987. The full year equivalent of $21.8m will be indexed in future years. No expenditure arises under this Bill from the change to allow regulations under section 9b of the National Health Act. However, the cost of providing for a new program of hepatitis B immunisation for at-risk babies is estimated at $2.8m in a full year.

The deregulation of private hospitals is expected to result in savings of $0.25m in 1986-87 and $0.5m in a full year. These savings should be considered in association with the abolition of the private hospital subsidy, which will save $90m in 1986-87 and $143m in a full year.
Business Impact Statement

The repeal of legislative controls over private hospitals is a substantial deregulation initiative and is in keeping with the Government's resolve to reduce regulatory controls over private industry. Care has been taken in the development of the new pharmaceutical benefits scheme to minimise the administrative input by pharmacists and to adequately compensate them where additional work is unavoidable. Pharmacists will be required to enter prescription details on the prescription record form, issue pharmaceutical benefits entitlement cards and to satisfy themselves that individuals have an entitlement to the benefits being claimed.

The new arrangements will also provide the opportunity for pharmacists to develop a closer and more professional relationship with individual patients with the obvious potential for increased business activity. They will also be relieved of the administrative work load associated with making claims of the Commonwealth for the 40 million prescriptions which will no longer attract a government subsidy. Their cash flow will improve significantly as they will receive immediate payment for these prescriptions rather than waiting for reimbursement from the Commonwealth.

The amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act will not affect the normal manufacture of satisfactory batches of biological products. Every effort will be made to avoid any delays by performing the necessary tests at the same time as they are being performed by the manufacturer. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation was introduced for a number of reasons and, without any apology at all, one of those reasons was the Government's desire to cut expenditure. I apologise to Senator Messner, who is not in the chamber, for having unwittingly misstated a fact yesterday when I said that a saving of $12m was the full year effect of this measure. The $12m saving is in fact that which is attributable to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. When making that point I had failed to take into account the additional savings because of the two defence retirement schemes and one other minor scheme. The full year saving from the legislation, in total, is over $17m. I apologise to Senator Messner for not having taken that all into account.

One reason the Government decided to introduce this legislation was to reduce government outlays, something which assorted members of the Opposition are all in favour of until it actually comes down to the specifics of doing it. The second reason was to provide equity between those who have retired from Commonwealth employment and those who are about to retire. As some people here would know-I doubt whether Senator Newman would, but some people in the Opposition would know-in the Commonwealth superannuation scheme the pension entitlement is tied to retirement salary and is then indexed annually by the consumer price index movement to the year ending March, with the adjustment being made from the first pension payment date in July.

Salaries have already been discounted by 2 per cent as from 1 July; that is salaries presently paid have increased in the previous 12 months or six months by 2 per cent less than the rate of inflation as measured by the consumer price index. Therefore, those who have retired from the Commonwealth Public Service within the last few months or are likely to retire in the future will have a lower pension entitlement because the pension is determined by the salary applicable at the time of their retirement and then adjusted for CPI movements. So, given that the salary they received had increased by less than the CPI, the pension that they would receive later likewise would be lower than it would otherwise have been. Therefore, had the Government not done this, there would have been discrimination in favour of those Commonwealth employees who had already retired compared with those Commonwealth employees who are about to retire.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is faulty logic in that.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point, less directly applicable, was that social security pensioners in general will, as a result of Budget decisions, have to wait for two months longer than they would previously have had to wait for the indexation adjustment of social security pensions. Indeed, it is below the point at which they are entitled to a partial social security pension. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mason asked whether, if the economic situation got more desperate, the Government would make any adjustments, clearly implying that the Democrats would not. That does not surprise me at all. The Democrats are off with the fairies. If there is a fundamental deterioration in the country's economic circumstances, such as a collapse of the terms of trade, of the type which has happened in the last 18 months and which has wiped $6 billion off national income, the response of the Democrats is to pretend it has not happened. That is what Senator Mason is advocating, that no matter what fundamental deterioration there is in the economic circumstances no adjustments in government policy should be made to accommodate that. It does not surprise me that that is the view of the Democrats, off with the fairies and Max Gillies as they are. I am grateful to Senator Mason for having drawn attention to the fact that it is the view of the Democrats that instead of making adjustments which are compatible with changed circumstances, governments should just pretend that the circumstances have not changed.

I now come to the amendment moved by the Opposition. This amendment displays something which is frequently displayed by the Opposition, and that is either culpable ignorance or wilful misrepresentation. That becomes apparent in the first paragraph of the amendment, which says-I paraphrase the words-that this piece of legislation seeks to discount the indexation of government pensions in anticipation of a discounting of wages in the national wage case. The actual words are:
. . . imposed by the legislation has not yet been proposed in a National Wage Case . . .

Has the Opposition not noticed that there has already been a 2 per cent discounting of wages? Indeed, if the legislation incorporated provisions which are compatible with the further discounting of wages which the Government is seeking, the discount factor would be 4 per cent, not 2 per cent. The amendment goes on to say:
. . . the Bill imposes on Commonwealth superannuitants, without consultation, a burden greater than that proposed for the community generally . . .

That is false. It seeks to spread the sorts of sacrifices, which the rest of the community has been called on to make, to people such as Mr Stone, who receives $33,000 a year pension at 57 years of age-I think it would have been a good deal more than that if he had retired at 65-and who has very substantial income, no doubt, from a variety of other sources. Referring to the defence forces schemes-this was the substance of most of Senator Newman's speech, which I presume Ollie wrote for her-the amendment states:
. . . discounting of . . . pensions further erodes conditions of service in the Australian Defence Force . . .

I observe for the record that the measure does not affect conditions in the Australian Defence Force because, by definition, it affects only people who have retired from the defence forces. The amendment continues:
. . . at a time when ADF resignations are at near-crisis level . . .

The argument was developed that a retirement pension lower than it would otherwise have been would be an incentive to members of the defence forces to resign. I found the logic of that argument curious. The logic, or rather the illogic, of the Opposition's argument is that paying a lower retirement pension encourages people to retire. Senator Mason, who is the Australian Democrats magician, apparently endorses that argument. That does not surprise me. The amendment continues:
(b) calls on the Government to direct the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal . . . to inquire into the adequacy of pay and conditions . . .

That is just a pure sop. In other words, it calls on the Government to surrender to a statutory body power over the determination of wages and conditions. That comes from the Party that purports to believe in deregulation. The last paragraph of the amendment argues that the Government should call for an inquiry into pay and conditions by some non-elected body and then automatically endorse its recommendations. My attention has been drawn to the fact that such an inquiry was conducted only 12 months ago-in September last year.

Most importantly of all, this cowardly amendment which the Opposition has moved does not address the major feature of the Bill-its effect on Commonwealth superannuation scheme pensioners. Frankly, the Opposition does not have the guts to criticise a measure which entails a marginal reduction in the benefits received by Commonwealth superannuation scheme pensioners. The Opposition does not have the guts to do so because it knows that it is widely, although somewhat erroneously, believed by the community that all Commonwealth superannuation scheme pensioners are fat cats who have been sponging to an unacceptable degree on the taxpayer. These sleazebags in the Opposition have moved this Clayton's amendment--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak at the Committee stage of the debate on Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. In doing so I thank Senator Michael Baume for his gallantry in coming to my defence against the ogre on the Government benches. I must say, however, that I have no need for such a gallant, nice though it is to have somebody riding in my colours. I assure Senator Walsh that bullying will not silence me. Bigger and better bullies have pulled my pigtails in the schoolyard and I am afraid they could not silence me either, so I think he is in a losing game.
—I give up. I suggest you learn something about unionism before you talk about it.

—I am not interested in whether the honourable senator gives up or not; I just warn him that he has a big job ahead of him if he wants to silence me. I draw the Committee's attention to the facts of this Bill because it is easy, with Senator Walsh muddying the waters, for its purpose to be lost sight of. I wish to outline the salient points relating to this legislation, which are of real concern.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, the pensioners of whom we are speaking today have their future pensions calculated on the basis of the consumer price index which runs from March last year through to March this year. So in a very real sense the costs to these pensioners of 15 months ago are now being met and paid for. Those payments have been made since the beginning of July. We are not talking about prospective income which is to be cut; we are talking about current income which is to be cut and that is a very different matter from future wage increases being discounted. This money which has accrued from 15 months ago to three months ago, which is currently being paid and which will be cut in October. That is a very different matter. It is a serious matter for all these pensioners, no matter what their former employment. It is sad but true that unions are much more concerned with their current membership, the people who are in work. Therefore, we have not had the sort of outcry that we would have had, had these people been in employment. No doubt there will be an outcry after this legislation is passed, which I fear it will be because it is part of the Budget measures. Nevertheless, it will be too late then and it will be one more case where this Government has cut into existing rights of citizens who have no opportunity to go before a tribunal and argue their case for themselves. This will be a fait accompli.

Reference has been made on this side of the chamber to Defence Force personnel because they already undergo so many disadvantages during their employment years. I made it very clear in my speech last night that this is one more condition of service which is being diminished by Government, which we can ill afford as a nation. Morale is extremely important in the Services and the whole country will be poorer if it is reduced further. I do not want to speak at length on this measure, but let us not forget that we are talking about a 2 per cent cut in existing income. We are not talking about 2 per cent of a future rise but about current income which will be cut in October. That is the disgrace of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is somewhat difficult for me always to vote on a second reading amendment-and such was the case with the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Bill 1986-because I have no input in the formulation of proposals put forward by the Opposition. I did not vote for the second reading amendment by the Opposition because I perceived that it was not entirely correct in that it said in paragraph (a):

SPEECH.PARA: expresses its concern that the level of discounting of superannuation . . . pensions imposed by the legislation has not yet been proposed in a National Wage Case, let alone given effect by a decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission . . .

The fact is that discounting in national wage cases is not unusual at all. I will just give an example: From memory, in the five cases up until the January 1981 case discounting did occur and it occurred due to the oil parity pricing policy of the then Government. So discounting is not unfamiliar to workers of this country. Reasons have been given for discounting other than the ones given in the recent case. However, I voted against the Bill not because I believe that superannuitants should not bear an equitable share of the burden of the crisis in our economy but because I am not sure whether this is the best way of achieving that equitable result.

Let me explain why I feel that way. If the attempt is to provide a basis for equitable treatment between workers and retired workers, consideration must be given to all factors relating to the wages of the workers. If those wages are to be discounted, there is a basis for retired workers to apply the same sort of self-discipline that is applied to workers. However, if that is to be applied, if there is a productivity increase in future, how will that be reflected in the amounts of superannuation paid to retired workers? Workers are entitled to make claims not only for productivity but also on work value grounds. Just as an example, if a superannuitant retires from the Commonwealth Public Service as a class 5 and that class 5 position receives a substantial increase as a result of a work value case, is it then a matter for the Government to consider whether that increase should be reflected in some way in the amount of money that is paid to the retired class 5 worker? These are the sorts of considerations which come to mind.

The other aspect is that I notice that the Government, probably wisely, does not present this as a permanent issue. As I understand it, it is only a one-off thing. It may occur next year, but it is a one-off at present. In case the Government is considering it as a permanent arrangement, it would be worth while bearing in mind that the total wage aspect of the decisions of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission may not be with us for very much longer. In fact, there is a growing body of opinion among unions that we ought to go back to the old basic wage and margins concept. That would enable the Commission to apply cost of living adjustments more equitably among the work force because they would be applied to the basic wage content. So, if a percentage increase were granted we would not have a situation where the tall poppies got an increase of $80 a week and the lower paid workers got an increase of only $8 a week. I very strenuously oppose the total wage concept. The basic wage and margins concept enables workers in a skilled area to apply for work value assessments. It also enables workers in unskilled areas to apply for work assessments on the basis not only of their value but also of the conditions under which they are performed. It may well be that simply by concentrating only, as we do in this Bill, on the discount aspect of a national wage decision we may not be taking into consideration all the factors which should be taken into consideration if there is to be an equitable sharing of the burden between workers and retired workers.
