TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, which we are about to debate, implements the changes to the present health legislation which have been made necessary by the Government's Budget measures. There are to be amendments to the Health Insurance Act, the National Health Act and the Therapeutic Goods Act, as well as minor amendments to a number of other Acts. The main amendments which the Government is implementing are in complete opposition to repeated assurances and, indeed, commitments that the Government has given the people of Australia. Without doubt they will impose further burdens on families already badly hit by this Government. These families have been asked to tighten their belts but they just cannot go any further with the burdens that this Government has placed upon them.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me remind the Senate of the glories of the new health system. Let us remember when Medicare first came in. We were told that we would pay one per cent of our taxable income as a levy, which was never to be increased, of course. In return, the Government would give us free hospital care and the services of the doctor on duty. Medicare would pay 85 per cent of the doctor's schedule fee. Not only that, but we would never have to pay more than a $10 gap for medical services as long as our doctor charged the schedule fee. Again, the maximum contribution for our pharmaceutical benefits would be $5 or, if one was entitled to the concessional benefit, $2. It was wonderful stuff. Those who were privately insured were told that, while they could not insure for medical fees or the gap for a medical visit, they could insure for the doctor of their choice in a private hospital and the Government would help pay the bill for that hospital and give them a bed day subsidy which would be paid directly to the hospital. After all, that was only fair because a part of that levy that they were paying was for the so-called free public hospital service, and if one did not use a public hospital the Government would help with the private hospital bill. How times have changed.

When the new scheme came into being the Opposition warned the Government that the legislation was too open-ended. We knew that the system would slowly and surely send the Government broke. Well, we were partly wrong. It has not been slow. Very rapidly and surely the Government is going broke. We all remember well those first wonderful promises that Dr Blewett made. As I have said, he promised that the one per cent levy collected by the Government would cover Medicare and would not be increased under any circumstances. We also remember well the Minister's promise that the levy amount would be shown separately on everyone's pay slip to allow us to know just how much our health care was costing us. We were all told as well that there would be a ceiling on that levy so that we would not be forced to pay an unjust amount. We remember the Prime Minister's letter which said that health care would be cheaper for everyone.

What has happened to all those promises? The promise that the one per cent levy amount would be shown separately on the pay slip never got off the ground. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) was advised that that was an error and that it would be a continual reminder to the taxpayer of how he was being slugged under the wonderful new system. So that promise was broken before it had even started. The next promise to go was the one that said that the levy would cover the cost of Medicare. That promise blew out in the first year; Medicare has been funded by Consolidated Revenue for years now. The next promise to go was the one that said that there would be a ceiling on the levy-a ceiling that would stop unjust health tax being collected by the Government. That was lost last Budget without so much as a bat of an eyelid. I believe that injustice was always intended and that talk of a just scheme was only rhetoric. Now, finally, the promise that the one per cent levy would remain, that there would be no increase, has also bitten the dust. That levy was increased by 25 per cent in the Budget. It was only a few months ago that Dr Blewett assured the Opposition that we were only being mischievous by suggesting that that one per cent levy would be increased.

What about the $10 maximum gap payment for medical services? In the Budget that has been doubled to $20. The $5 maximum for pharmaceutical benefits has also been doubled to $10. The $2 maximum for concessional pharmaceuticals has been increased to $2.50. In the pharmaceutical benefits scheme for pensioners, prescriptions have been considerably limited. Many of the most common drugs have been removed from it. From 1 November war widows and their dependants will no longer be allowed free prescriptions through the repatriation scheme; free prescriptions will be allowed only through the pensioner pharmaceutical benefits scheme. This will limit the drugs which are available to them.

The Minister assures us that there will be a safety net whereby no individual or family will have to pay for more than 25 prescriptions in any one year. After that number, he tells us, all prescriptions will be free. I wonder how long that promise will last. After all, one has to be pretty sick to have 25 prescriptions a year. I hope the Minister is not laying himself open to yet another area in which there could be abuse by fiddling the numbers. He tells us that he will monitor that, but I wonder how long that pro-mise will last.

Why have these changes been necessary? How will they affect the Australian population? The Treasurer (Mr Keating) assures us that the Go-vernment has created times so tough that Australia is in danger of becoming a banana republic. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) tells us that he has created a crisis so bad that ours is like a country at war. We all have to pull in our belts, he tells us. Mr Keating tells us that, because Australia is becoming a banana republic, he will grab back from the taxpayer $29m in a full year in increased payments for Medicare services and $143m in the abolition of the patient subsidy to private hospitals. He tells us that the taxpayers will have to pay an additional $67m for changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, as well as various other small amounts for deregulating private hospitals.

The truth is that these cuts were always going to happen. How often have honourable senators heard me and my colleagues in this place tell the Government that this had to happen, that Medicare would send it broke? How often have we told the Government that the cost of the care is out of control? We have said it everywhere; we have said it repeatedly. We have asked questions in Estimates committee hearings hundreds of times. Hundreds of times it has been debated in this place. We keep telling the Go-vernment that it will at least have to stop the bulk billing for everyone, that it will have to limit that bulk billing to pensioners and others on low incomes, or it will send us broke. I pointed out to Senator Grimes last time that Professor Penington had called on the Government to take this action. I pointed out that Professor Penington-one would hardly say that he is politically motivated-had said that the health care costs were out of control.

We have pleaded with the Government. The Government has turned a blind eye-blinded, of course, by its ideology-and it has refused to listen. It will have to listen eventually because the economy is so bad. Instead, the Government has stuck to its ideology; it has stuck to wanting to socialise health care. Once the doctors are fully bulk billing they will have been socialised. The Government has responded to the crisis in health care costs by limiting to the public hospitals funds that are needed to cover the enormous increase in the usage that the introduction of the levy has created. Not many people can afford to pay the levy as well as private insurance, so there has been a large flow out of the private system into the public system. The queues at the public hospitals have got longer and longer. I have spoken about these queues so often that I am sure the Minister must be sick to death of hearing them, but I will repeat the figures because constant dripping may wear away the hardest stone and he has to take action eventually. The latest available figures are: For Victoria, 27,750; for South Australia, 4,200; and for Tasmania, 4,300. For just those three States, the total is 36,250. The other States do not like to keep those figures. As I said in the debate on this matter in the Senate last time, of the 27,000-odd in Victoria, 6,299 patients are waiting for orthopaedic surgery and about 1,500 children are waiting for beds at the Royal Children's Hospital. I said:

What a shemozzle. What a dreadful situation. Let us look at New South Wales. Even though the New South Wales Government does not supply figures-one must ask why-the estimates are that the situation is very similar. There are about 30,000 people on the waiting lists in New South Wales. Those requiring orthopaedic surgery have to wait 24 months for their hip replacements. Children requiring admittance to hospital have to wait up to nine months.

As I said, in my State, 4,300 people are waiting for private hospital beds. What will these new changes do to those queues? It is very obvious that the queues will continue to grow. Because of the abolition of the patient subsidy to private hospitals, the health insurance industry will be forced to raise contribution rates. That additional cost, plus the extra 25 per cent levy, will signal the death knell for many individuals and many families that are now struggling to maintain their private health insurance. Once this happens they will be added to the queues at the public hospitals. Is this really what the Government wants? Will it go to that extent to socialise medicine? I guess it will. Dr Blewett, in his second reading speech, said that the increase to the private hospital insurance will be minimal. With the insurance funds having to make up $20, $30 or $40 a day, depending on the classification of the hospital, for their insured patients, there is no doubt that the contribution rates will have to increase. The injustice of this is enormous, when one realises that from now on everyone who privately insures gets absolutely nothing back from that part of the levy which covers public hospital accommodation that they will not be using. What excuse can the Government possibly have for such unjust legislation? It is socialist ideology.

Since the introduction of Medicare the health system has been in a thorough mess. Nurses have gone on strike for the first time; patients cannot get into hospitals; doctors have resigned en masse; and confidentiality of medical records has been violated. Our Medicare cards were accompanied by a letter from the Prime Minister congratulating us-remember that letter-for becoming members of the most wonderful health scheme in the world. It is a bit reminiscent, is it not, of the title of the best Treasurer in the world? That wonderful Treasurer, Mr Keating, has presided over the downgrading of the Australian credit rating to second grade, just as the Prime Minister has presided over the downgrading to second rate of the so-called best health scheme in the world. It has lost its rating along with Australia's credit rating. It is a second class scheme that denies to the ordinary Australian access to public hospitals, because there are long waiting lists, and increases the cost for private hospital insurers by putting such insurance beyond their reach. Thus, the ordinary Australian has no recourse but to enter the queues of the public hospitals. On behalf of the Opposition, I move:
At end of motion, add: `, but the Senate-

(a) condemns the Government for its latest attack on the private sector by increasing the cost of private hospital insurance, putting it beyond the reach of many ordinary Australians and thereby condemning them to long public hospital queues when they need hospital care;
(b) condemns the Government for its total failure to address the mounting public hospital crisis and the growing number of people on queues for public hospital beds;
(c) notes that under Medicare there are long queues for public hospital beds while there are empty private hospital beds;
(d) expresses its grave concern for the people reliant on private hospital care, such as is provided by the Victorian Bush Nursing Association; and
(e) calls on the Government to make fundamental changes to Medicare to allow people the choice of Medicare cover, thereby restoring the balance of demand for hospital beds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986 and the amendment just moved by Senator Walters. I wish to refer to the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in relation to the Bill. In report No. 13 of 1986, the Committee states that the purpose of the Bill is to:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) increase the maximum gap payment between the Medicare rebate and the schedule of fees from $10 to $20; and
(b) provide for the deregulation of Commonwealth controls over private hospitals and the abolition of bed day payments to private hospitals.

I shall return to the implications of that deregulation. The report states also that the Bill seeks to amend the National Health Act 1953 to abolish the present isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme and provide new arrangements under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I want to refer specifically to that part of the report that deals with clauses 41 and 42 which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee heads as `ill defined administrative powers'. The Committee's report should be looked at by the Government. I hope that, in Committee, the Government will explain those clauses. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee report states:
Clauses 41 and 42 insert new sections . . .
the Committee numbers them-

The new sections provide that the Secretary to the Department of Health `may', by notice in writing, require a manufacturing corporation to give notice in writing to the Secretary of each batch of a biological product produced or to be produced in Australia by the corporation and to furnish samples of such batches of biological products respectively. `Biological products' are goods for therapeutic use produced from organisms or the tissue or body fluids of organisms (including vaccines).

Although the new sections are both cast in the form of a discretion conferred on the Secretary, neither sets out any criteria for the exercise of the power and no provision has been made for review of the exercise of the discretion by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This raises two questions. First, is it intended that all manufacturing corporations will be required to furnish information and samples in accordance with the new sections (in which case the new sections might be better cast in a form which does not leave the Secretary a discretion in making requirements)? Secondly, if it is intended that some, but not all, manufacturing corporations will be required to furnish information and samples, on what basis is this discretion to be exercised?

The latter question could be of importance in two ways. A corporation which is required to furnish information and samples may consider the requirement onerous and may be justifiably dismayed if it discovers that similar requirements are not being imposed on its competitors. Equally, a consumer group which discovers that a particular corporation is not being required to furnish samples of its biological products to the Secretary for testing may consider that the Department of Health is shirking its responsibilities. In either case, in the absence of provision for the review of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or criteria for the exercise of the discretion it would be difficult to challenge the Secretary's use of the power conferred by the two new sections.
Accordingly the Committee draws clauses 41 and 42 to the attention of Senators . . .

Honourable senators should draw the report to the Government's attention and ask for an explanation of clauses 41 and 42 in order to eliminate what can obviously be gross abuses of these provisions in a number of specific ways which are revealed by the Committee. All the Committee's reports are serious. This serious matter deserves to be addressed in the context of this debate on the amendments proposed by the Bill. We are entitled to hear about that.

I want to refer to the implications of the legislation for users of health care, referring specifically to the position in the Australian Capital Territory. That is not a parochial thing to do, because I rely on an answer which I received on 16 April 1986 from the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) following my question on health care. I was told that health services were in a state of crisis and that the Australian Capital Territory was no different from the rest of Australia. It is worth looking at the history of what we have suffered under Medicare. The position will only worsen with the passing of this Bill. People will have to pay more for medical attention-an increase from $10 to $20 for a visit to their doctor. The private health subsidy is to be cut out. If people provide their own private health care cover, that means that, with the subsidy, the Government gets the cheapest possible hospital bed available. For some reason, the Government is intent on increasing the levy and gathering more unto itself to spend on the taxpayers' behalf. The Government is paying out less in the pharmaceutical area and paying out less for private hospital beds-gathering more and providing less.

The Medicare idea of universal care is a myth. It might seem to be universal care but it is not for someone who is sick and really needs help. If one is healthy, perhaps it is, but then it does not matter. Last year, the Sax report on Australian Capital Territory health services was presented. It stated:
Both hospitals are said by resident medical officers to have insufficient nurses in real terms of skill mix to the extent that even basic nursing observations were being omitted . . .
There are insufficient trained staff to handle more than one complicated delivery with foetal distress at any one time . . .
The obstetricians at this hospital are concerned about litigation arising out of unsafe care due to inadequate numbers of nurses . . .
The report referred also to nurses' work loads and the inadequate level of skilled nursing staff in some areas.

To review the situation, there have been problems with insufficient operating theatres available to be used when needed. Doctors have been working strange working cycles. Earlier this year, for a period, only one theatre was in service, which was used only for emergencies. There has been sufficient understaffing of pathology services to cause considerable and distressing delays in preparing reports for the Coroners Court and some delays in hospital services. For a time, no facilities were available to conduct EEGs. There has been an incredible number of union disputes and bans. Last year, there were two major linen disputes and the consequences in terms of surgery are still being felt.

I could spend half an hour talking about what is not available in the Australian Capital Territory for those suffering from mental illnesses. There have been times when ward B at Woden Hospital has not been fully operational. Not all voluntary patients can be admitted. People have been released or transferred early and there has been a lack of qualified staff and hostel accommodation. We do not have in this Territory the sorts of facilities to deal with mental illness that exist in the States. I do not know what the Government intends to do, but the stories that one hears constantly are distressing and the people who need help and support are not getting it.

As a consequence of the situation in regard to the operating theatres, the elective surgery lists, like those in the rest of Australia, have got longer and longer. Considerable personal hardships have been suffered by constituents in this electorate. At present 1,600 people are on the waiting list for surgery, which is quaintly called `elective surgery'. I think if most people were suffering the sorts of things that those on the list are suffering, they would have some difficulty being persuaded that the surgery was elective. But that is the word that seems to be used to cover such circumstances. Emergency cases are just about the only ones that really get into a hospital in this Territory.

I would like to drawn attention to some of the specific problems that have come to my notice. One concerns the recent case of a patient aged 68 whose doctor had been trying for eight days to get her into hospital. He finally sent her to hospital in an ambulance and she died in the casualty section. The doctor felt at the time that although her condition needed monitoring, there was no apparent emergency, and there was nothing to suggest that that was the case. The patient had had to be kept home and monitored during the period he had not been able to get her into hospital.

We have had difficulty getting a wheelchair for at least one spina bifida child. This matter has gone on and on. Constant requests for assistance have had to be made to the hospital and the Minister's office. I think we all remember the most distressing photograph on the front page of the Canberra Times earlier this year of a young boy whose surgery had to be put off, although it was very clear that he needed attention most urgently, because there were not enough beds available at the time.

There have been difficulties in the community nursing area. Nurses have had to close their books and not take in more patients for a time. I know of one case where a general practitioner, who was not able to get assistance for a patient of his, had to visit the patient twice a day to fill the role that a community nurse would have filled had there been sufficient nurses to maintain the load and the demand.

The story is well known as far as the elderly in Canberra are concerned. The Minister announced the other day that another 200 beds would be provided over the next three years, 180 of which would be hostel beds. No doubt these beds will be of great value. However, only 20 of the new beds are to be nursing home beds. I really think the Minister has been ill-advised in terms of the needs of the frail aged in the Australian Capital Territory. At present 240 people are classified as being in need of nursing home beds in the Australian Capital Territory. It is taking 12 months or thereabouts-and sometimes longer-to get into a nursing home bed. Many families have had to send their aged and frail relatives out of the Australian Capital Territory to parts of New South Wales to get them the sort of care they need. That is particularly distressing for the family which has to make the decision and, of course, for elderly people who have to be sent away so far from their relatives.

Many people in our hospital beds come from interstate. I think the Government is completely overlooking the fact that people from areas surrounding the Australian Capital Territory use our hospitals. Of course, it is appropriate that that should be the case because we have large hospitals which are capable of fulfilling that need. However, it seems most unreasonable that the frail aged, who are the ones least able to help themselves, should be put in a position where they are not able to get the assistance they need and should have to wait for such a long time for that assistance.

We had a case just recently of an 86-year old man who had broken his dentures. Normally a pensioner would go to a hospital and have his dentures repaired. This elderly man's daughter attempted to get him an appointment for this purpose. Although the man broke his dentures in July, he was given an appointment for October. His daughter was particularly distressed as she felt that this would have a serious effect upon her father. Because she has a handicapped husband she was not in a position to buy or arrange for a new denture. However, after some phone calls he was fitted in earlier, I think the system is very poor when one has to go to a local member to get a denture fixed. Other parliamentary representatives in the Australian Capital Territory can recount similar stories. Frequently, the only way of getting action in the health system at present is to go to one's local member. I resent the fact that that is the best that we can provide in this country when so much money is being spent on health care. We have a socialised medical scheme which provides universal health care. On the one hand Dr Edelsten is making so much money out of the bulk billing system and on the other hand my constituents are not able to get the service to which they are entitled.

I refer to an incident that occurred earlier this year concerning an elderly woman who had collapsed and badly cut herself and was almost choking on her own vomit. She was taken to casualty by her daughter and although she could not walk at the time she was told if she wanted a trolley she would have to wait. After seven hours, this elderly woman was admitted to hospital. The daughter wrote to me:
One did not need tests or instruments, only eyes to know that she was a very sick person.
But it took five collapses, vomiting after each, shock and fear, to convince the doctor that she should be admitted for treatment. The daughter stated further in her letter:

This is not an isolated case. My sister experienced a similar ordeal when her father-in-law was taken to the hospital after a massive stroke. It took five hours to admit him and he died 48 hours later.

We have had instances in recent times of the Meals on Wheels organisation not being able to be supplied with food because of union action in the hospital kitchens which supply the food. One can imagine how distressing that is for the people who depend on Meals on Wheels for their survival. We hear about home care, and all of us would want people to be able to stay in their own homes and in their own accommodation for as long as they are able to, provided that care is available to them. But when such a thing can happen to Meals on Wheels, which delivers voluntarily, I do not think that we are providing a very good service at all.

I was involved in a matter concerning a man who had a shunt in his brain and was finally operated on earlier this year after having been on a waiting list for nearly 12 months. This man had been on medication to deal with the pain that he was suffering as a result of having to wait for the operation. Every time he just about got to the surgery-in one case he was actually at the hospital-strike action closed the theatres for a period and he then had to go back to waiting. As I said, it was just on 12 months from when he was told that the shunt should be replaced before the operation was finally carried out. We have had problems in the area of podiatry, especially for a diabetic and arthritis sufferer who particularly needs care for her feet.

These are only a few of the instances. I have two bundles of letters, statements and newspaper cuttings relating to the problems from which people in the Australian Capital Territory have been suffering as a result of the health system and Medicare-as a result of the universal care which provides very little for those who need it but costs a great deal for those who are paying. Now, because the subsidy for private hospital beds has been withdrawn, more people will join the queues of those waiting for assistance at private hospitals. Because of the additional cost of the levy and because of the other expenses that will arise as a result of this Bill, fewer people will be able to care and provide for themselves as they have done in the past. We are moving totally in the wrong direction. We should be seeing that this country provides health care in such a way that people can get it when they need it at a cost which is reasonable. We should not have a situation in which people are being driven on to the public hospital lists. There are many people who ought to be able and who want to be able to have private cover and, if they need it, to be able to go to a private hospital. The $30 a day charge was not too much to pay towards that. As I have said, that represented the cheapest hospital bed that a government could find.

This measure will mean that fewer people will be able to pay the increased levy and what must inevitably be an increase in the voluntary insurance payments. More people will be waiting at the hospitals. The lists will be longer and those who have to be on those lists will be pushed further and further back and will have to wait longer. If that is the sort of health care socialism provides, it is time it was abandoned and we got back to a system that enables those who need health care to get it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —After that scrambled pot-pourri from Senator Walters and Senator Reid, it is a little difficult to know how to address all the nonsense they have put up. Some of the complaints they have listed are quite legitimate. We thank Senator Reid for a wander through the local electorate, but it is hardly the substance of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). Any one of us can pick problem areas in any number of portfolios, but it is ludicrous then to sheet home to the Government responsibility for all those areas. By the way, I wish to make it clear to Senator Reid that I am happy to follow her in this debate and I am sorry that she was discommoded by the fact that she changed her mind about where she appeared on the speakers list. That is her problem, not mine.

—I wish to take a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I beg the honourable senator's pardon. I have not changed my mind about the speakers list. I was listed to follow Senator Crowley and that is where I intended to speak. There is absolutely no reason to suggest that I am responsible for a change in the speakers list.
—There is no point of order.
—Peace!

—Senator Grimes should urge peace on them because they will not cop it from me. No, no, I am not feeling peaceful. I feel somewhat provoked. In fact, I feel amazed at what Senator Reid finished up with. She implied that all the problems and ills that lie around this country, with people who cannot get access to beds in hospitals and so on, are the fault of this Government. That is utter nonsense. Under the Fraser Government, more than two million people in this country were not insured and had no access to financial help for their health care. That is the situation the Opposition would like us to return to-a situation in which people do not know where to turn for financial security or access to medical care. The Opposition wants a two-tiered scheme. It wants the poor people to have no financial coverage.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has introduced a scheme that is universal. It has dealt with all those sorts of problems and it has ensured that nobody is denied access to adequate and comprehensive medical care in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they cannot get it.

—I find it quite interesting that Senator Reid suggests that there are waiting lists. We know that there are waiting lists. Ever since I started medical practice there have been waiting lists. I studied medicine quite a few years ago and there were waiting lists then. They are not new and they are not the fault of Medicare. There is no doubt that there are waiting lists and that there are problems. They are associated largely with the administration of public hospitals in the State arena. I acknowledge, as does the Government, that private insurance arrangements encourage people to use the public hospital system which leads to increased use of the public hospital facilities. Another reason why people use public hospital facilities is that they offer comprehensively good medical care. Of course people choose public hospitals. They are not places where people go because they are poor and wretched. They are places where one receives excellent medical care, where people train as medical students, as were Senator Walters's husband and I, and where, if one is crook, one prefers to go. There is a different categorisation of medical provisions in other than large public hospitals.

SPEECH.PARA: Waiting lists are a problem; we acknowledge that. They are not as large as Senator Walters has said, and the figures she introduced were about as murky as the ones that were fed to members of the Standing Committee on Social Welfare during its inquiry into private hospitals and nursing homes. People are listed in a number of places.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot even get into them.

—We know that there are long waiting lists. How much does Senator Walters think that that is due to these changes in the Medicare legislation? She wants to furphy people. She wants to confuse the issue. She does not want to address the root cause of the problem. She has also failed to address any of the pluses in this legislation that I would have thought she would be pleased to support. That may be beyond her.

SPEECH.PARA: The other contradiction contained in Senator Reid's contribution goes to her complaint, do you mind, that the Government is actually drawing in revenue but not spending it on people. That remark comes from a member of an Opposition that talks about the user pays principle and about privatising everything. The minute any changes even move that way, in the very progressive way that this Government is moving in a time of economic restraint, bleats come from the Opposition side that it is a terrible thing to happen. They say: `My God! Just what we say we want to happen is happening but we do not like it'. Honourable senators opposite should sort out which way they want to go. Their attitude seems very contradictory. If I were out in the community, I would be terribly confused after listening to what members of the Opposition have to say. Would they privatise the health area? Let us hear from them on that. We know that they intend to abolish Medicare. That should be very encouraging for most of the people earning below $15,000 a year, the pensioners and beneficiaries, all of whom presently are guaranteed health care without any worries at all. Above that, this Government acknowledges the option for people to choose to buy into private health insurance. The arrangements under this legislation and the figures done by the Government and the Department suggest that the increase in private insurance payments would probably be up to $1 a week, but that is not necessarily so. As I understand it, Medibank Private estimates that it will raise its fees by 50c a week. So we are not talking about huge increases that will massively disenfranchise people.

Senator Reid made a point about criticism from the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. As a member of that Committee, I am aware of that critique. I certainly made the comment in the Committee that I thought people perhaps were looking at this legislation without an appreciation of what the clauses in the Bill really address. For the edification of Senator Reid, under current legislation the Therapeutic Goods Act already enables the Secretary to the Department of Health to require the production of information and samples about production of biologicals. However, it became clear to the Government that that information the Secretary currently can retain does not allow for specific information about a batch release of biologicals. In other words, for example, the Secretary has the power to seek information about flu vaccines but not about a specific batch of flu vaccines. This legislation amends that provision so as to enable the Secretary, or in other words the Government, to have access to the information about batches rather than a whole type of biologicals. If Senator Reid is very concerned about that, she should be comforted by the other amendment in the legislation that enables the decisions taken by the Secretary to be reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Clause 46 of the Bill specifically extends the jurisdiction of the AAT to review this area. So the area of doubt raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has been addressed by the Government in this legislation. I will be surprised if, when the Scrutiny of Bills Committee receives the response from the Government, it does not find it acceptable. It is a problem when it is not understood how legislation will apply in a particular area, as in this case with the batch release system of biologicals. Senator Reid does not have too much to fuss about in that area.

Senator Walters made many comments along fairly recognisable and usual lines. She suggested that the Government was leading us all to rack and ruin and she mentioned the maintenance of bulk billing and so on. The Government is unashamed about maintaining bulk billing. This is for a number of reasons-partly because it goes to the heart of Medicare and partly because it is an option that doctors can exercise. Of course, it may be of some scandal to Senator Walters to discover that some doctors do decide to bulk bill. They are not coerced into doing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like Edelsten, and you would support that entirely.

—Senator Walters is an unmitigated disgrace. If ever once again she presumes to speak for me in this chamber, I will stand up every time and say: `I will speak for myself. Please do not impute motives to me'. I have said on other occasions that those systems are open to abuse and I do not presume that the way of Dr Edelsten is necessarily the way of the future. But this debate is not about Dr Edelsten. This debate is about maintaining bulk billing.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment about 52 per cent of all medical services under Medicare have been directly billed. The vast majority of those have been for services to pensioners and disadvantaged people. That is what the Government is very serious about in the Medicare legislation and in these amendments. We intend to maintain that coverage and provisions for the people who are least able to pay for their health care, to ensure that they are not financially disadvantaged by that. If there are some less than honourable doctors, that is nothing new to me, it ought to be nothing new to Senator Walters and it is not the way of funding a system for providing health care. I have said before that it is a shame that the medical profession, of which I am a member and of which I am very proud, is charged and abused by Senator Walters in a way which is quite disgraceful.

The other changes in the Government's legislation will also maintain that progressive stance that underwrites the Medicare legislation. If Senator Walters wants to call that part of this democratic socialist Government's policy, she has got it right; that is precisely what this Government is about. It is about charging the cost progressively to people. For Senator Walters's edification, not only are the changes progressive but also the introduction of the 1.25 per cent levy-the increase required under times of hard economics-will have a phase-in period.

The levels at which the levy begins to be paid have been increased. Where previously the level at which the levy started to be paid by a single person was $7,526, that has now been lifted to $8,030. For a couple, where previously the figure was $12,504, it has been lifted to $13,370. For each child, where previously the figure was $1,530, it is now $1,660. So not only have the base levels been lifted but also the phase-in period has been maintained. People will not have to pay their levies suddenly, because the Government recognises the complications that can cause, so it will be phased in. If Senator Walters looks at those figures, she should realise that the people at the lower end of income earning scales and those who are dependent on pensions and benefits are covered beautifully, as the Medicare legislation intended in the first place and as it maintains now.

Senator Reid's amendment to this legislation referred to other areas that the Opposition has not spoken about, which I find a bit surprising. I would have thought we would have heard some support from the Opposition for the changes to the isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme-IPTAAS. The Federal Government recognises that having the Commonwealth manage that scheme is inefficient and administratively cumbersome, particularly because the isolated patients by and large are living not in Canberra but in outlying areas of the States and they are seeking assistance and care in the States. It is quite appropriate and proper, and far more administratively streamlined, for the States to manage that scheme. In passing the isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme to the States, the Government has increased the funding by 23 per cent to assist with the passage and to recognise that its contribution is best in terms of financial assistance. The administration of the scheme will be much better done by those people in the States who know the requirements and are more appreciative of the travel demands and so on. That is one point which needs to be acknowledged and supported.

This legislation is important also for the changes it makes to the pharmaceutical benefits. The increase in the cost of prescriptions from $5 to $10, with an average prescription cost of about $7.30, will largely be a charge against people who are well and who do not pay for many prescriptions in each year. Not only is this Government distributing from the better off to the poorer off, but also in this way it is distributing from the healthier to the sicker people. People can bear very considerable costs if they have a chronic illness, or because of the stages of their life cycle. For example, families with young children may need a quite considerable number of prescriptions in a year. The Government, recognising that, has built a safety net in to the increased charges per prescription, so that after 25 prescriptions have been filled subsequent prescriptions will be filled at no charge. People who are currently entitled to free prescriptions will have that situation maintained and the pensioners' health card fee will go from $2 to $2.50. Essentially, the Government recognises that the principal problems with pharmaceutical benefits charges are suffered by people with chronic illness. It has recognised this by building in a safety net, so that after 25 prescriptions further medication for the year will be free, but those of us who may seek an appointment with a doctor and may require a prescription only once or twice in the year will be asked to pay a little more. I would have thought that most of us in the community would recognise that as manageable.

As ever under health legislation, it is important to note that, where difficulties have to be addressed, the Government-I particularly commend Minister Blewett-has been at pains to see that the cost falls progressively and fairly and falls least on those in our community who are least able to pay. There are many other changes in this legislation, one of which addresses the changes to non-sexist language in the legislation; a requirement when legislation is amended. I am certainly one of the people who is appreciative of that.

Another important area which needs some comment, apart from the lesser changes in the legislation, is the change to the hospital subsidies. One thing which needs to be realised is that, with the changes, the Government has recognised that historically a number of private charitable or religious hospitals have undertaken hospital care for needy, uninsured patients. The Government recognises the importance of that care and that contribution, so specific purpose lump sum grants will be provided to eligible hospitals to cover those costs which otherwise might have been lost under the changes in this area. As ever, the changes in the health area are thoughtful and progressive. They go very much to the heart of the legislation which was initially introduced as part of the first Hawke Labor Government program. They maintain the principles of progressivity, ensuring that nobody in this country is without medical cover or is disadvantaged from seeking medical care by the costs that might apply to them.

The Federal Government is acutely aware of the problems of waiting lists in hospitals and is doing what it can to address that problem. Certainly it is something that has addressed the mind of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), and changes in previous legislation have addressed that problem. For example, there has been an acknowledgment from the beginning that there should be a public system and a private system. This Government is quite aware of the value and contribution of private insurance. Previous changes recognised that privately insured people were being treated in public hospitals and arrangements were made to address that. The problems of public hospital management cannot all be sheeted home to Medicare. If Senator Walters goes around saying that that is not the case, she is just furphying, if not mischievously misleading people.

The problems of hospital waiting lists are not new. There are a number of reasons for the demands on public hospitals. One of the reasons is that that is where the excellent quality medical care and medical treatment happens in this country. It is also where the community has preferred to put its highly expensive and high technology medicine. We do not want CAT scanners or huge intensive care units for the maintenance of people with cardiac problems in all sorts of private hospitals. The community has recognised, by way of responsible management of health costs, that large public hospitals are the places where some of that more expensive and high technology medicine should be, so that also contributes to the demands made on the services of public hospitals.

We need to appreciate the very complex series of things which contribute to increased waiting lists in hospitals. For example, there are waiting lists for people needing hip replacements when not too many years ago artificial hips were not even known of. Developments in medicine also contribute to possibilities in surgical and medical treatment that were not previously known. Invariably waiting lists tend to happen in the initial stages when research and experimentation are part of the work, and these sorts of things will happen in public hospitals. That is another drain on the services and provisions of a public hospital scheme. I wish that Opposition members would appreciate the complexities and would be honourable and honest in the way they deal with them. I do not expect that to be the case. I commend the Government on the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am absolutely staggered that the public outcry from the people of Australia about the health care crisis has not penetrated the mind of the Government, particularly as that outcry comes from all sections of the community. It comes from doctors, patients, nurses, health administrators, ancillary health workers and so on. There is not one area in our health industry that is not unhappy and dissatisfied with the organisation of the administration of health in Australia today.
—You do not talk to the same people as I do.

—That may be the case. The Senate is debating the Health Legislation Amendment Bill, which will amend three Acts of Parliament and make ancillary amendments to minor matters. It will amend the Health Insurance Act, the Therapeutic Goods Act and the National Health Act. The Government is doing par for the course in a nationalised health scheme and is following what has been done in other countries. The Government will increase costs, the amount of regulation and control, but it will decrease the amount of service. This has been expected over the years. Opposition members have been making speeches on these lines time and again, but the Government goes along in its merry ideological way with a Health Minister who seems determined to keep putting the country into a strait-jacket. This is despite the cost blow-outs in Medicare and in the hospital sphere. These massive blow-outs will keep increasing to the detriment of the country and particularly of the patients, because after all that is what this is all about. I do not see why Australia should be plunged into rigours of this sort when the runs are on the board, we can see what has happened in the past and can predict what will happen in the future. As to anything we do not know, we only have to look at what has happened in other countries to see what is in store for us in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the present scene in Australia, one sees that thousands of public hospital beds have been closed down, particularly in New South Wales and Victoria. In Queensland we have been buffered by the presence of the free hospital scheme which has existed for 50 years. We have been able to maintain that scheme, despite the fact that this Government has held back on certain funds-Medicare funds, road funds and State grants-to Queensland. Queensland has been buffered because the Queensland Government has been able to maintain the free hospital system there, but other States are in dire straits. If the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) or any other Minister, or anybody, wants to look at the number of out-patients in any of the major hospitals in New South Wales, for example, he will see those hospitals are on a war footing. Why should that be the case in Australia? The talk about waiting lists is correct. Upwards of 100,000 people are now on those waiting lists. To say that they are on the waiting lists of different hospitals is ridiculous, because they are not. Perhaps patients have to put down their names for several nursing homes, but not for hospitals, particularly for elective surgery. Although there may have been waiting lists in the past, there have been nothing like the present waiting lists. One reason is the fact that a great squeeze has been placed on the private hospitals. If people cannot get into the private hospitals, it pushes them over to the public hospitals and increases the load there. That is exactly what is happening now.

Private hospitals have been categorised, which has caused the closure of three hospitals. They are also becoming accredited, which costs a great deal of money and for which private hospitals have to foot the bill. They have been put under nonsensical bureaucratic and administrative pressure which has nothing to do with curing patients. Accreditation has been tried around the world, particularly in the United States of America. An excellent example was in the veterans' affairs administration there, but all it did was to increase costs and decrease the quality of service; yet it existed principally to give quality assurance and to ensure that the costs did not go over a certain level. It had exactly the opposite effect. In fact, it turned out to be a minimal standard scheme, and it has now been scrapped.

However, we in Australia are taking this step and many public hospitals have gone in for accreditation. Some public hospitals have not been able to pass the tests and yet still operate. Their virtues have been extolled by Senator Crowley, who said they provide the best service; but I deny that. The public hospitals provide this service, but equally good service can be provided by private hospitals. Private hospitals, given a chance, are quite capable of handling complicated cases up to and including transplants. The fact that private hospitals in this country are precluded from having out-patients has restricted private hospital development for years. It is a ridiculous restriction. They should be allowed to have out-patients. The way in which ambulance transport is administered has restricted the development of private hospitals in Australia, particularly in traumatics. Private hospitals are not so good in traumatics because ambulances do not take trauma cases to private hospitals. That is simply because people are charged if they go to private hospitals, but not for admission to public hospitals. A public hospital cannot refuse a case and it is hard for an ambulance crew to pick up somebody who may be unconscious, bleeding, in pain and say `Hey, Charlie, it will cost you $20, $40 or $80 for us to take you to hospital', when they know they can take the patient to a public hospital which must accept the patient. Consequently this has stopped the development of traumatics in private hospitals. For years I ran a private hospital which had its own out-patients. I do not know how that was ever allowed, it must have existed historically, but we had a quite large traumatics department. I do not see why those restrictions should not be lifted to enable the private hospitals to develop. The more the private system is allowed to develop, the greater the load it will take off the public hospital sector.

I have been horrified to hear stories of other senators about the effect on sick people because of delays in admission. These stories are not just anecdotal; I have heard them myself. There are anomalies with those countries with which Australia has reciprocal agreements. Let us take the case of Yugoslavia. Because operative surgery is often delayed in that country and the black market in medicine over there is very big, patients in that country who cannot afford to have a major operation on the black market-they are priced on to the black market because of time constraints-find it easier to fly to Australia, have the operation here under Medicare and then fly back. They are still not out of pocket. I have heard those sorts of stories. One hears stories about our rich America's Cup colony making use of Medicare here when they should be provided for under their own insurance schemes. Bulk billing, which has already been mentioned, is the cause of many of the problems in Australia today and much of the drug problem. I have heard stories that in Sydney any self-respecting dole bludger can go around at least 20 doctors in a day and get about 15 prescriptions for tranquilliser-type drugs. Then he can take those tablets up to Kings Cross, flog them for about $10 a tablet and use that money to finance his drug problem or habit. One can sheet that home to bulk billing because not only can such people get their prescriptions under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme but also the bulk billing means that they do not have to pay for their consultation at all. But the Government has to pay the doctor for those visits. As I mentioned before, the waiting lists are aggravated and generally the Medicare system is not one that will work in this country.

We can take the example of Queensland over the years where there was a free hospital and out-patient system and a private system as well. About half the people wanted to go public and half private, and I am pretty sure that that is how it would work in Australia if we allowed public and private sectors to operate in harness. This would allow the Government to perform all the functions that it needs to perform-looking after pensioners and other beneficiaries, veterans affairs, workers compensation, medical education and areas of research. The whole system could work quite comfortably and happily if the private sector were not being strangled as it is today.

This Bill alters the isolated patients travel assistance arrangements. We will just have to wait and see how that works. It means that the Government is transferring the function to the States. I notice that it is giving them a little more money than is provided for at the moment. Generally, I am in favour of that type of move-handing jobs back to the States. However, I do not know the detailed arrangements of this transfer. I support the amendment to the motion that has been moved by Senator Walters and point out once again that the Government is on the wrong track by just increasing controls, regulations and costs in all areas, or pretty well all areas, against the promises that it has made. It is a very frustrating feeling to know that one's country is going further down the drain because of these changes to the health Acts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). This Bill seeks to make a number of significant changes to several facets of the way health care services are provided in Australia. The main features of this Bill are that it proposes to increase the maximum patient contribution, or Medicare gap, payable by individuals from $10 to $20; increase maximum patient contributions payable for pharmaceuticals from $5 to $10; abolish the Federal subsidy to private hospitals; abolish Federal regulatory controls over private hospitals; and abolish the isolated patients transport and accommodation assistance scheme. On the face of it, many of these changes appear to be retrograde steps to be taking in a country which supposedly provides services according to need ahead of ability to pay for health care. To some extent these measures might be seen as the beginning of a return to the user-pays principle. Such a move would be of significant concern to the Australian Democrats, who supported the introduction of what was intended to be a universal and equitable system of health care financing for this country. Fortunately there are back-up measures relating to most of the amendments made by this Bill which will enable some balancing of the desirability of a reduced domestic deficit with the needs of the disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: Like the Government, the Democrats appreciate the desirability of some reduction in public sector spending in our current economic circumstances. Unfortunately, many of the Government's proposed expenditure cuts in the human services areas do not meet with the stated goal of restraint with equity. There is no question that postponing pension indexation and poverty trap abolition places a thoroughly iniquitous burden on the already underprivileged, and the Democrats have already made it clear that our intention is to oppose those measures when they come before this place. However, as I have said, the initially draconian appearance of some of the proposals in the Health Legislation Amendment Bill does in fact belie some constructive improvements which are being proposed by the Government.

The first substantive change contained in the Bill is the amendment by clause 5 to increase the maximum patient contribution payable in respect of a medical service from $10 to $20. This increase will be of any effect only in relation to services costing more than $67, as this is the level at which the gap between Medicare benefits and schedule fees reaches $10. While around half of the services listed in the schedule cost more than $67, I am advised that in terms of the frequency with which procedures are performed, only about 5 per cent of services cost over this amount. The maximum gap which an individual will be required to pay out-of-pocket in any one year will remain at $150. This safeguard for the chronically ill was, of course, one of the amendments to the originally proposed Medicare scheme for which the Democrats fought long and hard. With the maximum patient contribution in relation to individual services increasing, it is all the more important that this total maximum payment be retained. It is pleasing to see that the Government has extended the Democrats' commitment to providing for the chronically ill into the pharmaceuticals area, and I will return to that point later.

We recognise that there has been no increase in the maximum gap since 1978, and that Australia still has one of the world's cheapest health care systems. The maintenance of the repayment of 85 per cent of the schedule fee means that it is still a real option for the medical profession to avoid passing on the cost of the increase in the gap to the disadvantaged by direct billing. For these reasons, the Democrats will not be opposing the increased maximum patient contribution.

The reforms contained within this Bill with the most significant ramifications flow from the deceptively brief and simple words of clause 7. It is this provision which simultaneously removes Federal regulation and subsidisation of private hospitals. There is little controversy in relation to the abolition of Commonwealth controls over the approval and categorisation of private hospitals. All States have some role in regulation of private hospitals, and the States certainly are better placed to be conducting planning work, such as the regional allocation and redistribution of hospital beds. Not only has the States' work been duplicated by Federal involvement in this area, but also it has been hindered. State control of private hospitals will allow not only for more regionally appropriate policies, but also for more flexible and innovative-not to say entrepreneurial-approaches to provision and administration of services.

The private hospitals and insurance funds have welcomed the proposed deregulation. Indeed, the various industry groups worked together on a working party which has produced a report containing recommendations for a system of patient classification which replaces the present hospital categorisation. This arrangement will ensure reimbursement more accurately reflecting patient needs and services provided, and will be administered within the industry. The development of these proposals has been an impressive example of industry co-operation in this area. Less impressive have been the comments of the Opposition's shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) which indicate that he is unaware of this working party and its report. He seems to suggest that this deregulation is merely a replacement of Federal regulation with some sort of categorisation at State level. Such a landmark co-operation should be more worthy of note by the Opposition.

The concomitant initiative to deregulation, of course, is the abolition of Federal subsidies for private hospitals. The Democrats are conscious of potential problems with the abolition of the private hospital subsidy. In fact, we have looked carefully at a number of concerns relating to choice of and access to health care services. The first concern was that the subsidy abolition might restrict access of people whose preference was for private health care to the services of their choice by making private insurance prohibitively expensive for many. Without this Commonwealth funding private hospitals might pass these increases on to the consumer as either higher health insurance premiums or out-of-pocket hospital costs.

The second significant concern, which flows from the first, was that if people were forced to abandon their private cover an inordinate strain would be imposed on the already badly overstretched public hospital system. The variables in all this, of course, are the level of increase in insurance premiums and the elasticity of demand for private insurance. It seems that an increase of around $1 to $1.50 a week for basic table cover for a family unit is expected if the whole cost to hospitals of subsidy abolition is passed on to contributors. Other figures of up to $2.50 a week have been suggested. It is expected that the Government will put some pressure on the insurance funds to absorb some of this increase through the substantial reserves that many funds have accumulated. It has been impossible to get any real assessment of just what figure is likely, why, and with what consequences.

A further concern about which the Australian Democrats have been approached by relevant organisations is the effect of the abolition on those charitable, religious and community hospitals which have provided health care to needy uninsured people. There are, undoubtedly, some people for whom it has a special importance to sick and dying be cared for in a hospital administered by, for example, a particular religious group or charity. A number of hospitals have received the Federal subsidy in relation to patients, although they have not in fact been privately insured. A small number of such hospitals have a large proportion of their patient load in this category. Consistent with the priority we accord to freedom of choice in health care, the Democrats welcome the Government's intention to provide replacement financial assistance to such charitable and community hospitals which fulfil the criteria, including their reliance on such assistance, for their continued viability.

The third area of major change foreshadowed by this Bill is that of pharmaceutical benefits. Clause 21 provides for an increase in the maximum patient contributions towards the cost of pharmaceuticals from 1 November. The cost to concessional beneficiaries will rise from $2.00 to $2.50, and the maximum paid by the general community will increase from $5 to $10, although the actual cost will often be less than $10. The Democrats will not oppose these increases, as we recognise that they will be the first since January 1983, are broadly in line with increases in income since then and, most importantly, because the Government is simultaneously introducing a commendable scheme to protect the interests of the chronically ill in the community. I will return to this in a moment.

The impact of these Budget measures on the availability of pharmaceuticals to pensioners warrants special reference as the Democrats have been approached by a very large number of pensioners who are concerned about this. The Budget does not introduce any charge for pharmaceuticals to pensioners or sickness beneficiaries holding health benefits cards or their dependents. Many pensioners have had the mistaken impression that the Government's proposed delisting of 46 items from the pharmaceutical benefits schedule is part of these Budget measures. While that move will undoubtedly mean some savings in this area for the Government, it follows not from pre-Budget meetings seeking funding cuts but from the deliberations of a panel of medical experts on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. Many of these deletions are undoubtedly warranted on medical grounds, such as products being superseded by superior drugs which remain on the free list. Many of the products will still be available to people over the counter in pharmacies and indeed in supermarkets. They will simply not be free.

The Democrats have been concerned about the proposed deletion of some analgesics and in particular antihistamines. Despite our requests for an explanation, the Government has not accounted adequately for the difficulties which will result for some pensioners from this action, particularly people with chronic allergies. Despite our attempts to reach a compromise with the Government, we have not, as yet, been able to gain agreement on a mechanism which will provide for some of these people and we are continuing to pursue this course.

The Government has introduced a laudable and long overdue scheme in its Budget measures as a safety net for chronically ill users of pharmaceuticals. Pursuant to clause 19, from 1 November no individual or family or concessional patient will have to pay for more than 25 prescriptions of items on the pharmaceutical bene- fits schedule in each calendar year. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
