SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —A short time ago, the Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, announced that he wanted to set up a space station in north Queensland. It was envisaged that such a project could be completed sometime in the 21st century. Whilst the idea may have some merit, two important factors should be kept in mind. Firstly, Queensland members of parliament and parliamentary hopefuls are preparing for an election and any statement which covers up the gross mismanagement of the State is welcomed by the ruling National Party. Secondly, Sir Joh's announcement must be seen against some of his previous grand schemes. Although $93,000 has reportedly been given for a feasibility study for the space port, that is far short of what Sir Joh was prepared to outlay for another venture.

SPEECH.PARA: This involved the infamous Dr Oskar. The Premier backed this Paraguayan businessman who claimed he would establish an oilseed plant in central Queensland. That seems, on the surface, a commendable action, but that perception vanishes when it is realised that Sir Joh's backing involved a loan guarantee of $6m from the State Government. It turns out that Dr Oskar was an eccentric visiting foreigner. Maybe that is the reason the Queensland Premier got on with him so well. After the Premier railroaded the $6m loan approval through the State Cabinet, untoward stories started to emerge about Oskar. Sir Joh, in typical fashion, described these stories as `claptrap and a load of hogwash'. Oskar's oilseed and processing plants in Fiji, New Zealand, Western Australia and Ireland had all failed with debts of $20m. No-one but the Premier of Queensland wanted Oskar. The then Treasurer, Llew Edwards, did not. Minister Mike Ahern would not have a bar of him. Yet the Premier's ardent support for a man who operated from Room 1907 of Lennons Hotel seemed to know no bounds. Finally, it became evident even to the Premier that Dr Oskar was at best a con man and more probably a crook. The Premier allowed the issue to fade away. Maybe his party organisation got to him and told him to drop Oskar before they were both pulled under.

Although the reason for my next comment may not be initially seen, I must mention that by far the greatest majority of Queensland residents live close to the coast. One reason for this is that rainfall in the inland is low and unpredictable and thus agriculture and grazing become increasingly more difficult as distances from the coast increase. But rainfall is generally plentiful along the coast and this may have had something to do with Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen becoming hooked on a so-called hydrogen car, the major fuel for which was supposed to be water. On this occasion, the Premier made no financial commitment towards manufacture of the car. Hungarian-born and self-styled inventor of the hydrogen car, Stephen Horvath, told media representatives that the State Government had no financial involvement in his project, but that he had the moral support of the Premier and his Government. The car was described as working this way:
Employing a V8 engine, the Horvath system supposedly involved passing a 40,000-volt current through a chamber filled with hydrogen.
A small amount of hydrogen in the form of deuterium is transformed into helium via a so-called thermonuclear process, which creates the energy source.

It is not surprising that Mr Horvath's claims were not universally embraced. A scientist from the University of Queensland said if the car worked in the way described by Mr Horvath, anyone driving it would be dead within ten seconds from a lethal dose of neutrons. The same scientist also said it would take a temperature of 40 million degrees to bring about the fusion reaction of deuterium. Sir Joh was not worried. He declared: `It's fantastic. All you've got to do is put water in the tank'. The car was brought to Brisbane and Sir Joh attended a lunchtime launching. The launching was reported as follows:

`It's arrived. It's here, right before your very eyes,' an enthusiastic Sir Joh told the lunchtime crowd. `I forecast today will go down as a very special day in our history. This is cheap, pollution-free and readily available: it's just water.'

The Premier stepped from the dais, drank a cup of water from a bright, lime-coloured can and poured the rest into the tank. But as he moved to start the car there was an embarrassed silence. A few minutes later Sir Joh announced: `Mr Stephen Horvath's mechanic has gone somewhere with the keys and we can't catch up with him . . . but I'm sure all you people can have a good look at the car, so long as you don't touch anything.'

Sir Joh drove away in a petrol-powered vehicle and, shortly afterwards, one television station, lampooning the Premier, announced it was planning to unveil a machine which would turn lead into gold. Whether the keys to the car were ever found remains a mystery.

Subsequently jailed cancer quack, Milan Brych, a Czech, was another of Sir Joh's favourites. Brych was a charlatan who preyed on those who had terminal cancer. He set himself up in the Cook Islands after being deregistered in New Zealand. He should never have been registered in the first place, but peddled his so-called `cures' for fantastic sums in New Zealand and the Cook Islands. Many of his patients came from Australia and he wanted to set up a cancer clinic in Queensland. He gained Sir Joh's approval and may have succeeded in his quest if it had not been for the persistence of Dr and later Sir Llew Edwards, the Deputy Premier of Queensland. Dr Edwards saw Brych for the quack that he was. Brych actually came to Brisbane and Sir Joh was ecstatic. He said: `We've a tremendous opportunity of getting a clinic here. It would become a centre of this method of treating cancer'. Dr Edwards, however, would have nothing of it. A report states:

`He will not be registered by the will of the Premier or by the wish of the Premier,' Dr Edwards said. `As far as I am concerned, he is finished. He has left a sad story in Australia, a sad story in the Cook Islands, and the quicker he is forgotten, the better.'

He was not about to be forgotten, however. He went to California where he was subsequently jailed and was released only recently. At his trial he was described as a con man, thief and charlatan, something suspected years ago by almost everybody in Queensland, except Sir Joh.

I would like to return to the proposal for a 21st century space station in north Queensland. When I heard of this, I was reminded of a less grandiose scheme which was put forward by the then National-Liberal coalition during the 1977 Queensland election campaign. That was a commitment to build a rail link to the Moreton Bay centre of Redcliffe, a facility long overdue for the people on the Redcliffe Peninsula. Needless to say, nine years later, the link has not materialised. Perhaps the question is now: Which will come first, the space port or the Redcliffe rail link?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —More than three years ago the Hawke Labor Government announced that it intended to acquire some one million hectares of land in the Cobar area, within the Western Lands Division of New South Wales. The Defence Department and the Government indicated that the purpose of that major acquisition was to have an Army manoeuvre area. There was, of course, from that moment for the many families that had lived there-some of them for a century or more-a very harsh series of compulsions. They were under the threat of acquisition and therefore unable to sell their land or make decisions within the normal commercial situation. That may have been justifiable for some months; it could not be justifiable for the many years that have passed.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the Government made the announcement and has never made any decision subsequently has created quite inhumane conditions for many Australian people. Families are undergoing great economic stress. Indeed, there is some suggestion of marriage breakups because of the difficulties that are being faced. It ought not to be possible for a government virtually to freeze land over this lengthy period and deny ordinary families their right to choose whether they hold or sell their properties. The situation becomes even worse. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in a letter to Mrs Mary Turner in Orange and to the Hon. Ralph Hunt of the Opposition, the honourable member for Gwydir, made it perfectly clear to both of them that the Government would neither compulsorily acquire land nor forcibly dispossess people. Yet, in fact, the Government will not face up to that letter; there has been no recanting of it at all. The evidence has been brought out and yet the people themselves, having had that assurance, cannot act.

Land values have depreciated very severely and what is called a blight has come upon the whole of the area. This becomes doubly worse because in the Estimates Committee E inquiries it has become clear that no money at all has been put forward in this Budget for any land acquisition or for any purpose, including environmental impact studies, in the Cobar area. That could mean a number of things. It means that the Government may have decided to do nothing and to surrender the land; if that is so, it should answer and tell the people that. It may mean that for another financial year the people of Cobar are going to suffer that inflexibility and that blight. I repeat that this is a ghastly, inhumane situation and it ought to be resolved.

Three months ago, following the tabling of a Senate committee report rejecting Cobar, I wrote to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) drawing attention to a very personal problem of one of these people in Cobar and I asked for some speedy action. I had to write two days ago and remind him that three months have gone by and nothing has happened. I have had no substantive reply to a letter to this Minister in three months. I say that at the very least that is grossly inefficient and reflects the gross, cavalier attitude of this Government. At the worst it is totally inhumane because that particular family, facing enormous economic problems, has had no answer at all and has had to go on day to day.

This Senate referred to a committee-the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence-an inquiry into the question of a training centre, an infantry training and artillery training centre, in Bathurst-Orange and a manoeuvre centre in Cobar. That Committee tabled a very lengthy report some three months ago. Prior to its report, it became absolutely clear to the Government that it was a farce to go ahead with Bathurst-Orange; that every item of the Army's user requirement could not be achieved, none of them could be achieved in Bathurst-Orange. In fact, the Army relinquished it. The Senate Committee had before it overwhelming evidence that Cobar was totally unsuitable for use in a manoeuvre area. The user requirement was for, in fact, a corps exercise involving armoured units, Leopard tanks, heavily armoured vehicles, and some 3,000 men and materials, digging holes, making trenches, cutting down fences, and invading a territory which, by its very nature, is one of the most sensitive areas in an ecological background in Australia.

The Western Lands Division was established by the State Government of New South Wales many years ago to protect the land against exactly this kind of outrage. The land itself is highly sensitive. It is largely arid country, a very low rainfall area-maybe eight or nine inches a year-and when the rain comes it comes in one heap; for the rest of the year, often it is a dust bowl, lightly covered with scrub and some vegetation, but very little; water courses that are absolutely dry for most of the year; and only small hills from Dubbo westward, almost a flat plain. Yet here was the Defence Department and the Government saying that this ought to be an Army manoeuvre area to be invaded by heavy Leopard tanks and thousands of troops who, in fact, would tear up the countryside. The user requirement by the Army was that it needed nice rolling country with running water courses, timber and vegetation, so that it could have a whole range of different conditions, none of which exists in Cobar. So the Senate Committee itself reported that it ought to be rejected, and I read its conclusion:

In summary the Committee concludes that the proposed manoeuvre area at Cobar does not meet the Army's own user requirement. A reconnaissance by Army personnel, though seriously restrained by refusal of access to private land, found that large areas of the site were of little training value because of limitations imposed by terrain and vegetation and that in the case of water crossing operations the site offered no possibility of realistic training . . . The Army reconnaisance report went so far as to raise the question of whether the Cobar area, given its sensitivity and featureless terrain, would in practice offer any increase in training potential for a mechanical brigade over that which already exists at Shoalwater Bay in Queensland.

The Senate Committee, of course, concluded outright that it was a nonsense situation and a great assault upon the sensitive ecology of the area to go into that area, but the Committee also said that since the Government's strategic appreciation indicated that any threats were likely to come from the north in sub-tropical or tropical areas, the training of these units should be in that kind of situation; a situation totally foreign to Cobar itself and to the Western Lands Division. It also indicated that the strategic appreciation had pointed out that in such an onslaught on Australia there would not be the need for corps force movements and heavy armoured units.

Therefore the last thing that the Army would be wanting in terms of the strategic appreciation of the Government would be a place like Cobar which bears no relationship whatsoever to the sub-tropical areas; no relationship to the terrain at all and certainly would be raped by mechanised forces. But the Dibb report on the Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, which now the Government has embraced, states:
The Review notes that its proposals for a reduced emphasis on mechanised and armoured operations may affect the basis of selection of a new fuel firing and manoeuvre area.

So the Dibb report rejects Cobar in a diplomatic way. In fact, the Dibb report strengthens the concepts that if there is to be training, it should be up north where there is the likelihood of incidents; it should be in small, independent groups, lightly armoured groups; and a corps force with Leopard tanks is ridiculous for that situation.

So that at every level Cobar has been rejected. The Army, which did the reconnaissance itself, has rejected the situation; Dibb has given an entirely different scenario. The Senate Committee over many months has rejected the situation and yet year by year the people there are suffering a gross assault upon their rights and freedoms. Gross damage is occurring to their families and to their economic situation and the Government does nothing. It will not even answer a letter after three months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Arrogance.

—Yes. What kind of arrogance and impertinence is this? But the Senate Committee report, of course, said another thing. It was interested in this whole question of land acquisition, and there is still a reference before the Senate Committee on this matter, waiting upon the Government which promised it some six months ago to bring in an amendment to the Lands Acquisition Act; but it has not been here and we are still waiting on it. The Committee faced two particular problems and a dilemma. It had had the letter from the Prime Minister stating emphatically that there would be no compulsory acquisition and no forced dispossession. Why, then, should there be any blight at all?

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody knows that no landowners would willingly and voluntarily give up the land that is theirs; that is, given the free choice. The Government has known this situation and yet on this goes. It is one of the worst outrages I have seen. The all-party Senate Committee itself-unanimously, incidentally-said in its recommendation:

Thus the Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government clarify its policy on the compulsory acquisition of land in peacetime for defence purposes before proceeding further with evaluation of the Cobar site.

I repeat, Madam Acting Deputy President, that there is no money at all in the Budget for Cobar for any reason. That is a clear statement from the Estimates Committee and that can mean a number of things. If it does not mean that the Government has put aside this thing, it must mean that for another year these people are to be forcibly frozen in terms of their land and the devaluation of their land. I repeat: I know nothing more inhumane than that kind of approach. There is no money; it is not going to happen; there is no environmental statement. It is true that the Western Lands Commissioner, Mr Pearson of the New South Wales Government, is undertaking a survey and, if that means that this is going to drag on for another year, this Government ought to be totally censured for one of the worst breaches of human freedom that there could possibly be. How much more do we want? We have a Senate Committee report that condemns it; we have Army reports that condemn the situation; we have no money in the Budget and, of course, no answers from the Government. I rise to say that I urge the Government in the name of humanity to give us an answer and to free the people of that area from the present blight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise today the question of a particular kind of VIP flight; that is, the VIP flight that has, on occasions, been used to take a member of the other place, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, from what is purported to be his home base of Sydney to the place where he lives away from home, which is Canberra, and where he receives, in fact, a living away from home allowance by living in Canberra. On a recent television program-I forget on which channel-there was an interview involving Mr Keating and, as I recall it, his wife, on the way back from attending an evening function in what is now described as his home base of Sydney. They were returning, having been to that function in Sydney, to Canberra by VIP aircraft.

SPEECH.PARA: At that hour of night it would be very difficult to establish that the Treasurer was returning to Canberra in order to perform some official function which, of course, would be an appropriate use of a VIP aircraft. Coming to Canberra for official reasons is naturally and properly done by Ministers of the Government and, on occasions, by, in fact, office-holders; in other words, Opposition members and senators. There is no complaint about that. The issue is whether it is proper to use a VIP aircraft to go from what is purported to be one's home base in order to come to Canberra, not for official purposes, but in order to be in one's living away from home location and to be paid $95-as it was then; it is now $100-a night for so doing.

The concept of catching a VIP aircraft to fly to Canberra to earn $95 in living away from home allowance strikes me as absurd. There is an impropriety. I am not quite certain where the impropriety lies. Does it lie in having as one's stated home base a place where one does not live, thereby enabling one to get living away from home allowance in the place where one does in fact live with one's family-that is Canberra-or is there impropriety in using a VIP aircraft to be taken to Canberra for a purpose which is clearly not an official purpose? In other words, the flight is to come to Canberra to be with one's family and for no other purpose than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —So that he can get his travel allowance.
—As Senator Reid says, so that he can get his travel allowance. The reason I raise this-
—You do not know whether Mr Keating had an official engagement in Canberra or not.

—If he had an official engagement at the time he was getting that aircraft, Senator, I would be overjoyed to find out because, if you watched the television program, you would see that it was late at night. He had been attending a ball, of all things, in Sydney. I know this Government is enthusiastic about calling meetings all the time, but if a meeting was called to take place in the early hours of the morning in Canberra on that night, I would be grateful for the information.
—Cabinet often meets beyond midnight.

—As a result of Senator Ryan's intervention, I would now suggest that it would be proper if the Government were to provide the Senate with details of every occasion on which the Treasurer has flown, from Sydney in particular, at night to Canberra, particularly on those occasions where it would appear that there was no official function for him to attend in Canberra and that the only purpose of his return-

—You are making allegations based on speculation. You don't know why he returned to Canberra. You do not know what his commitments were the next morning, what time they started. It is a fact that Cabinet meetings often go beyond midnight.

—I thank the honourable senator for her intervention. The fact that she is now questioning the proposition I was putting underlines the need for the Government to come clean and tell us. What are all the occasions? We know from watching the television, from seeing this program, that late at night the Treasurer and his wife returned to what is allegedly their living away from home spot, having left their so-called home base.
—You do not know why.

—We know the reason he does not stay in his home base is that in fact he has no accommodation in his home base and his accommodation is permanently here. But as the senator has intervened, all I say to her is that I look forward to receiving the information so that if on no occasion the Treasurer returned to Canberra simply to live away from home and had no other function, happily I would withdraw any suggestion of impropriety.
—Perhaps you should find out before you make it.

—The interesting thing is that the Government appears to be very reluctant to come out with information. It has to be dragged out of the Government in this area. For example, the Cabinet decision which increased the capacity of Ministers to get a living away from home allowance by living in Canberra was never conveyed to office-holders in the Opposition, to whom this would have a specific relevance. A decision was made in 1982 by the previous Government which clearly handled this matter. In fact, Senator Sir John Carrick, as I recall it, released it in this place at the time. Mr Howard referred to this the other day by saying that the Hawke Government had significantly widened the eligibility of Ministers to receive travel allowance by broadening the interpretation of `principal place of residence'.

SPEECH.PARA: According to Mr Hawke, the Treasurer's principal place of residence is where he does not live and that seems to be the situation. Back in 1982, Mr Justice Mahoney, in response to a request from the then Government, said:
In the end, the question whether a particular place is the principal place of residence must be determined according to the ordinary meaning of the term and the facts of the particular case.

In December 1982, Senator Sir John Carrick said that the Government had interpreted `principal place of residence' as meaning the place where Ministers and office-holders resided for most of the time or where their family was normally based. That seems a pretty reasonable and rational definition. That definition has now been overturned, secretly, and ultimately released only when the Government was put under pressure to do so, just as I hope I am putting the Government under enough pressure to reveal information about these VIP flights. The burden of Mr Hawke's response to Mr Howard at the time was that this definition was established clearly by Mr Justice Mahoney.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a point of order that Senator Michael Baume is clearly breaching the agreement reached between Government and Opposition about the use of this time. This is a free time for senators to raise matters that they wish to place on record, but there is an agreement between Government and Opposition that the time not be used for raising controversial matters which may end up in a division being called for.

—On the point of order: My understanding of the agreement from the Whips' meetings is that it is a time when we have speeches in lieu of first reading debates, which does not mean that they may not be controversial; in fact, I understand there to be no agreement that they are non-controversial; that they are in lieu of first reading debates when this type of topic could in fact be brought up and debated.
—I thought that matter had been discussed previously, and that matters of general interest were to be raised. I ask Senator Michael Baume to keep within those borders.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. In fact, some correspondence recently took place between the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) which in fact broadened the base on which these discussions could take place; in fact, as I understand it, this emerged from the Government calling a quorum on me when I raised the question of the Treasurer's language and read into the record a whole range of offensive language that he had used in the other place. It was following that that the question was clearly resolved, as I understand it, in the correspondence.
—I raise a point of order. Is Senator Michael Baume challenging your ruling on this matter, or is he carrying on with the content of his speech?
—I was simply referring the Senate to the substance of correspondence that passed on this very matter of the point of order. I am dealing with the matter of the point of order.
—We know exactly what has happened and you are debating the issue of the Acting Deputy President's ruling.
—Senator Baume, I think perhaps you should keep your remarks within reason.

—Right, Madam Acting Deputy President. I basically got up to note that the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday, 20 September had in fact written an editorial to which I had replied. I had sent a letter to the Editor of the Sydney Morning Herald replying to the burden of that editorial, which related to the general question of living away from home allowances. Unfortunately, the Sydney Morning Herald decided not to print my response, and for whatever reasons it had it is entitled so to do. But the fact is that this editorial raised this question and made the point-the argument went on for some time-of the absurdity of singling out Mr Keating for special treatment. It went on:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the sensible notion of a travelling allowance for Members of Parliament has become a rort. Perhaps Mr Keating, who is leading the war against tax-free rorts, deserves special attention. But the Opposition should not forget that many of its members are participating in the same rort.

I am making a general point about this whole question of living away from home allowances and what is held by the newspaper to be a rort. I wrote a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald, responding to that editorial, in the following terms:

The Opposition has `singled out' Mr Keating for attack over his travel allowance for a reason that your editorial defending him strangely ignores: Mr Keating has received a tax-free benefit of more than $30,000 over the past two years by making a declaration that is patently false.
He is obliged by the Remuneration Tribunal--
this question of what one declares as one's home base affects all of us; it affects every member and senator--
to declare as his home base for travel allowance purposes his `permanent place of residence'.

He has chosen to declare a house in which he has admitted he does not live as his `permanent place of residence' in order to receive a living away from home allowance while residing with his family in Canberra.
His Canberra address is the self-acknowledged permanent place of residence under the Electoral Act; he is listed there in the Electoral Roll.
I do not know whether this affects any other senators or members. Perhaps if it does, some change in the arrangements should be made. I go back to my letter:

His defence that the only house he owns is in Sydney, is nonsensical; the requirement is `place of residence', not `ownership' of a house, otherwise he could, like his similarly peripatetic ALP colleague, Mr Unsworth, claim a weekender in Tweed Heads as his home base.
Then I deal with the question which I have raised about catching VIP aircraft to go back to Canberra. I then go on:

These flights to Canberra are one reason the official figures suggest he may have spent no more than 11 nights in his `home base' of Sydney last year while spending 182 nights living away from home with his family in Canberra and receiving $100 a night for doing so.
I also suggested to the Sydney Morning Herald as follows:

I do not recall your mounting a similar defence of Mr Tony Street several years ago when he was criticised over living away from home claims made before the previous Government instituted stricter rules about `home base', which the Hawke Government appears to have removed. Surely what was sauce for the Liberal gander should now be sauce for this Labor goose.

Madam Acting Deputy President, there is a problem. It is clear that the Sydney Morning Herald editorial has identified it. We have a problem relating not simply to place of residence but also to the use of VIP aircraft. I thank the Minister for her intervention and I am certain that her interest in making certain that the Senate is fully advised on this matter will be, in fact, translated into revealing the information that the Government has so far not revealed.
Sitting suspended from 1.22 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce both in his own capacity and also as the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Minister's welcome remarks in the Senate yesterday afternoon that community recognition for commercial success was at the forefront of the attitudinal changes needed in Australia. I quote the remarks which the Minister made in this place:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the more we recognise success in business and innovation in industry the more success will follow from that recognition.

I ask whether the Minister is aware that, referring to the recently published list of the 200 wealthiest people in Australia, the Prime Minister told the audience at a function in Brisbane last month:

Assets of hundreds of millions of dollars in individual cases, a lot of which, and this is not said with any sense of anger or envy, has been, or most of the overwhelming majority has been, obtained illegally.

I stress those words `most of the overwhelming majority has been, obtained illegally'. I tell the Minister that I ask this question because of the outrage of at least one member of that two hundred who, to my knowledge, has made his money very honestly indeed. I ask him: Given his acknowledgment of the need to recognise commercial success, will he dissociate himself from the Prime Minister's generalised slur on a group of very successful Australians?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not retreat in any way from what I said yesterday, that this country would be better served if there was a wider community recognition of success in business and innovation in industry. I can only assume that the Prime Minister was talking about tax avoidance. That is not an industry which we in the Government particularly admire, although it got a very easy go from Opposition members when they were in government. I think the Prime Minister was probably referring to that fact. Certainly I would not embrace in my remarks the tax avoidance industry as one worthy of high praise and recognition from the Australian community.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question following that non-answer. I am quite happy to quote again the Prime Minister's remarks when referring to those 200 Australians. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: Assets of hundreds of millions of dollars in individual cases, a lot of which--
or most of the overwhelming majority has been, obtained illegally.
I ask whether the Minister dissociates himself from that generalised slur; or does he support it?

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly I am not as informed as the Prime Minister about those matters. I do not know the context in which those remarks were made. If the Prime Minister was talking about the 200 people in the Business Review Weekly list, I make the point that a lot of them have been business successes and I guess a few of them have been involved in tax avoidance from time to time. After all, it was par for the course when honourable senators opposite were in government.

—I bring to the attention of the Minister representing the Attorney-General the South African film The Gods Must Be Crazy, which has been showing for extraordinary lengths of time in most Australian capital cities and which beyond doubt seeks to raise sympathy for the separatist policies of the South African regime. What action is the Government able to take to curb this sickening display of misinformation? Will the Minister investigate the possibility of covert South African funding being used to prop up the showing of this film long after its commercial viability has passed?

—I have not seen the film in question, so I cannot possibly make any comment about it. The brief I have from the Attorney-General on this subject is to the following effect: The Film Censorship Board registered this film in 1983 and classified it as NRC, not recommended for children, and later as PG, parental guidance. The film was found by the Board to have a simplistic plot involving slapstick violence and some crude language which caused the NRC classification. The film has been exhibited in other countries, including the United Kingdom at the 1981 London film festival. The Film Censorship Board did not find, as it was able to do, I suppose, that this film was undesirable in the public interest, using regulation 13 (1) (c) of the Customs Cinematograph Films Regulations, through racism or its advocacy of violence. But there is, of course, a view current in the community, which Senator Elstob's question reflects, that this film may be, in its simplistic caricaturing of black people, regarded as a tool of South African misinformation. That issue has been debated in the Press. I am not, as I said, in a position to make any judgment about it. However, other comments made about the film, here and overseas, are to the opposite effect, that the film is uplifting and that it knocks about local ideas of racial superiority. So, I suppose, as with most things, one's judgment of the character of the film depends on the eye of the beholder. Beyond that, I am not able to make any comment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I remind him that Mr Keating defines `principal residence' widely for his travel allowance but narrowly for Australian home owners. To mark last Saturday's anniversary of the introduction of the capital gains tax, I ask whether the Minister is aware of the circumstances in which a taxpayer's principal residence is subject to capital gains tax and under what circumstances, if any, the tax exemption for the principal residence would be available for a person who rents his premises and lives in another house.

—Subject to confirmation-because I am not sure that I can accurately remember the details of this-I believe the position is that a person may own one residence and, whether living in that residence or not, that residence continues to attract exemption from capital gains tax if it is sold, provided that the person does not own another residence at the same time. That is exactly the position which Mr Keating is in. He owns only one residence, and I believe that, should that be sold and should there be a real gain on it, there would be no taxation levied, but I will have that confirmed.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy both in his own capacity and as Acting Foreign Minister. The Minister will recall my earlier questions concerning the Chernobyl disaster and international arrangements that might be put in place as a consequence. What progress has been made, particularly by the Australian Government, since the Chernobyl accident, towards minimising the effect on neighbouring countries of any similar future accident, whether it occurs in the Soviet Union or elsewhere? Further, what has been done towards providing international assistance to a country which suffers a nuclear accident or radiological emergency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to tell Senator Tate that Australia will, along with a number of other countries, tomorrow sign two major new international nuclear safety conventions in Vienna during a special International Atomic Energy Agency conference. One of the conventions provides for early notification of a nuclear accident with potential transboundary effects, and the other provides for emergency assistance in the event of a nuclear accident or radiological emergency. Australia played a very major role in launching the negotiation of these conventions as a matter of priority following the Chernobyl nuclear reactor accident, which demonstrated manifest gaps in current international arrangements for nuclear safety. I mention, in parentheses, that the final report of the working group of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission was tabled in the Senate yesterday. This report sets out a detailed description of the causes of the accident and its implications as they are now perceived to be. In a Press release back in May, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, had identified the main gaps thrown up by the Chernobyl accident as the absence of an effective early warning system and multilateral emergency assistance arrangements, and urged the negotiation of international conventions.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the notification convention a state is obliged to notify other states which may be adversely affected and the IAEA of a nuclear accident involving its military and civil facilities and activities, except nuclear weapons. In relation to nuclear weapons, Australia welcomes the statements that were made last night at the special conference in Vienna by all five nuclear weapons states that they would also notify, within the framework of the convention, any nuclear weapon accident which has or which might have significant radiological effects on another state. As a party to the notification convention, Australia will promptly be provided with detailed information about major nuclear accidents, particularly those that could directly affect Australia. This will enable Australian authorities to cope more effectively with the effects of a nuclear accident involving Australia or Australians overseas.

The other convention, the assistance convention, provides a framework for the provision of prompt assistance by states and the IAEA to a country which requests assistance following a nuclear accident or radiological emergency. Under this convention Australia will be able to seek assistance within an internationally agreed framework in the event of some nuclear accident or radiological emergency affecting Australia. The convention also provides an internationally agreed framework for the provision of assistance should Australia wish to assist another country in similar circumstances. It scarcely needs to be said that the Australian Government welcomes the conventions as a practical and timely response to the Chernobyl accident, but the overriding objective must remain the prevention of nuclear accidents.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer the Minister to a recent newspaper item in which he is reported to have assured the head of Peko-Wallsend Ltd, Charles Copeman, that he personally supported mining in stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu National Park. Has the Minister's support for mining in stage 3 of Kakadu been conveyed to Mr Copeman, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd or any other representatives of the mining lobby in advance of the Government's final decision on that question? Is the letter to Mr Copeman not further evidence that Government policy-making is under the direct influence of the New Right? Has the recent spate of attacks on the New Right, including on Mr Copeman, by the Prime Minister and other Ministers, been an attempt to deflect attention from this frightening trend? What assurances is the Minister prepared to offer the large number of conservation minded Australians that their concerns will have any bearing on Government decisions on this or any other matters when pitted against the New Right lobby?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines's question contains it own answer. So, far from the decision with respect to Kakadu stages 1 and 2 demonstrating the influence of the New Right, I would have thought it was a spectacular demonstration of how little influence the New Right had on the Government's final decision. I cannot recall putting anything to anyone in writing about stage 3. I have, of course, had some conversations, in particular with BHP, about the implications of a stage 3 declaration for various mining lease interests, including Coronation Hill, which is a lease of BHP. I might well have had similar discussions, as I do on many occasions, with representatives of the mining industry about the issues that will have to be weighed and balanced by the Government in coming to a final decision on that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: I can assure Senator Haines and the Australian Democrats, and anybody else who may be interested in this matter, however, that no decision that the Government makes about stage 3 or about the sequence in which stage 3 is declared will in any way put at risk the basic objective, which was identified by Mr Justice Fox and to which the Government readily accedes, of protecting the catchment area of the South Alligator River from environmental pollution in any form. That remains a priority that must be satisfied. Any conceivable mining activity that may go ahead in stage 3 will go ahead only if it can satisfy, as I have said on numerous occasions, stringent environmental standards, which will mean that it does not impinge in any adverse way on the South Alligator catchment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it correct that the Australian Taxation Office in Sydney is entering into a contract on a trial basis to have some of its data processing work keyed by private contractors? Is it also true that the work could be done for the same cost or less in the Taxation Office itself and that the approximate cost of this scheme, $55,000, will be taken from funds allocated for salaries and wages? If this is true, what security arrangements will be undertaken to ensure that the confidentiality of information provided by taxpayers will not be jeopardised?

—There were three parts to the honourable senator's question. I understand that the answer to the first part is yes; that is, that the Taxation Office in Sydney has contracted out some data processing work. I received a letter a few days ago from, I think, the Federated Clerks Union of Australia on the same subject. I annotated it along the lines of: Please get in touch with the Treasurer, firstly, to see whether the facts which were stated similarly in that letter are correct and, secondly, the reasons for the Taxation Office taking the action which it apparently has. Whichever comes in first-either a reply to my direct personal question to the Treasurer or a referral of this question from the Senate to the Treasurer-I will get the honourable senator a definitive reply as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer the Minister to an answer that he gave yesterday in relation to Queensland charges. Does the Minister realise that the figures that he quoted then are selected State and local government charges from the Australian Bureau of Statistics consumer price index series? Does the Minister understand that the local government component of these charges is greater than the State government component and that State Government does not control local government charges in any way? Is the Minister aware that, in the last 12 months of a Labor administration, the Brisbane City Council charges rose by 16.3 per cent compared with the national capital city average of 7.8 per cent and that, under the present Liberal administration for a similar 12-month period, they rose by only 5.3 per cent? Is this further evidence that the Australian Labor Party is a bunch of tax gatherers, as an examination of tax in State Budget papers and ABS catalogues will prove?
—Order! The honourable senator's question was getting a bit too long. I remind him of what I said yesterday.

—All the excuses and apologias in the world do not alter the fact that, according to the ABS index of government charges, in the last two years charges in Queensland have increased by 50 per cent more than the capital city average and by about 50 per cent more than the consumer price index.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, who would be aware of severe overcrowding and complaints from the public caused by heavy passenger traffic at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and the International Airport in Sydney. Will the Minister indicate what Government initiatives are contemplated to solve these problems? Would the use of the existing rail line for passenger traffic to the city be considered in any review of the problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators from New South Wales and those who have to use Sydney Airport for transit reasons will appreciate that the problem of passenger traffic into and out of Sydney Airport has got increasingly more difficult. I think that is largely because of the congestion that has been apparent at Sydney Airport for the last 20 years. The previous Government was not prepared to grasp the nettle and take the step of establishing an alternative site which this Government has provided in recent times. However, in the interim, in preparing for the construction of a second airport, the Government has taken steps to handle the increasing levels of traffic until such relief is provided by that construction to which I have referred.

ANSWER.PARA: The airport will therefore require expansion of existing facilities to cope with that increasing traffic that I have mentioned. A $19m project is under way to augment the taxiways, with $4.8m to be spent in the current financial year. Another $22.61m-at June 1986 figures, I am advised-is to be spent on a project to improve the international terminal building. That is to be commenced later this year, with $3m to be spent in the current financial year. There will be an interim system to exhibit aircraft call signs and altitude and radar displays at the Sydney area approach control centre.

The Prime Minister and the Premier of New South Wales have agreed that a committee of Commonwealth officials and State officials, known as the New South Wales Airfields Committee, will examine a number of issues relating to the problems of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport to do whatever else is necessary to improve passenger flows into and out of Sydney Airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that a new and fourth inquiry is to be set up into the Australian War Memorial, will the Minister for Veterans' Affairs wait until he receives the report of the latest inquiry, or will he continue his spiteful personal vendetta, carried out under parliamentary privilege, against the professional character of the Museum's Director and against those members of the Council who he assumes do not share his extreme left wing views?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing personal in respect of the differences between the way in which I regard my responsibilities as a Minister to the Parliament and the people of this country and the administration of the Australian War Memorial; it should function properly. Several matters came to my attention and I referred them to the Council for consideration. The Council, at its meeting yesterday, unanimously agreed to call for a further investigation into those matters. I have agreed to its suggestion that the investigation will continue, or a new investigation will commence, depending on negotiations on Tuesday next week between me and the chairperson and other senior members of the Council of the Australian War Memorial.

ANSWER.PARA: I have agreed to the Council's request to grant leave to the Director on full pay until the inquiry has completed its investigations. In the meantime, I will appoint an officer from the Department of Veterans' Affairs to act as administrator of the Australian War Memorial, as I was requested to do in the communications conveyed yesterday to me by the chairperson in Brisbane when I was attending some veterans functions there.

There are a number of serious matters and I believe that it is my obligation as Minister to have them properly investigated. It has never been suggested at any stage-except in the question asked by Senator MacGibbon-that there has been a clash of personalities. I have handled these matters by referring them officially to the Australian War Memorial Council. The Council has met to consider the matters and yesterday spent several hours determining the matters. It found that the matters required further investigation. I will co-operate with the Council to realise the objectives of proper administration of the Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a supplementary question, Mr President. If that is true, why has the Minister made assertions about the actions of the Director and the Council in advance of the reports of the committees of inquiry?

—I did not make any allegations. A number of matters were drawn to my attention which showed that there were aspects that required investigation by the Council. I put those matters in the hands of an investigator appointed by me from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Those matters will be considered by the new investigator who is yet to be appointed.

Senator Chaney-On a point of order, Mr President: I do not see how this matter fits within the Minister's ministerial responsibility. It seems to be an at-large question relating to a foreign former head of state.

—My question is directed to you, Mr President. Do you believe that such language in any circumstances is unparliamentary? —Has the Minister for Education seen recent Press reports which indicate that the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has assessed Australia as one of the few countries that will see an improvement in prospects for youth next year? Can the Minister outline reasons for this positive assessment of the Federal Government's youth and education policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —All honourable senators who have been concerned about high levels of youth unemployment will welcome the OECD's assessment, which is that significant improvements have been made in reducing those levels of youth unemployment and that we in Australia can expect those improvements to continue. I think that Australia is the only Western country in the OECD about which that forecast can be made. I think that there should be bipartisan welcoming of this news.

ANSWER.PARA: It is certainly worth placing on record that the Government's education policies have significantly contributed to the improved situation for youth. In 1985 about 46 per cent of our young people were completing a full 12 years of education, in contrast to less than a third when we came to office. The improvement in youth allowances, which we announced in the Budget and which we will implement over the next few years, will lead to a further increase in those in education. The number of students in higher education places is now at a record high, with 300,000 places in 1987 for young people in higher education, contributing further to opportunities for young people to avoid unemployment.

It is worth pointing out that the contribution of education is significant in more than a statistical way. Young people who are staying on to finish their schooling or taking up places in colleges of technical and further education and other higher education institutions are equipping themselves better for the jobs that exist when they go on to the labour market. When we announced our increased participation strategies some scepticism was expressed as to the value of keeping young people in the education system at a time of high unemployment. But, clearly, the high employability of our graduates and the demand on the labour market for young people with TAFE qualifications of various kinds demonstrate that education is making a massive contribution not only to reducing youth unemployment but also to producing a more highly skilled and productive labour market. As I said at the outset, I think that all honourable senators should welcome these developments on a bipartisan basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs will be aware that the Parliamentary Disarmament Forum will be held here tomorrow. My question concerns Australia's contributions to achieving progress in arms control and multilateral disarmament. Has the Australian Ambassador for Disarmament indicated this week cautious optimism that a universal chemical weapons ban may be achieved within 12 months? Also, what is the Australian Government's assessment of three other developments this week, namely, the reopening of the Geneva negotiations; the breakthrough for arms control in Europe, announced in Stockholm; and President Reagan's constructive speech to the United Nations General Assembly? Finally, in the Government's view, what continuing role is there for Australia and Australian initiatives in these developments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the first question about chemical weapons, it is the case that the Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr Richard Butler, has expressed optimism about the likelihood of concluding a chemical weapons treaty in the light of very encouraging progress over the course of the recently concluded session of the Conference on Disarmament in Sweden.

ANSWER.PARA: On the second question about the reopening of the Geneva negotiations, it is the case that both sides have now put forward a number of detailed proposals in these bilateral negotiations, including a recent exchange of correspondence between President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev. These envisage substantial reductions in their respective nuclear arsenals of the order of 30 to 50 per cent in strategic weapons and an interim agreement involving reductions in intermediate range nuclear forces. They also address the difficult and contentious issue of research into strategic defences being conducted by both sides. In addition, there have been two meetings recently in Moscow and Washington between the United States and Soviet arms control experts to help prepare for the United States-Soviet summit. I should say that these matters were also discussed in Mr Shevardnadze's meetings with President Reagan and Secretary Shultz over the last few days. The Australian Government hopes, of course, that these developments will pave the way for substantive negotiations on deep reductions in offensive nuclear forces in the sixth round of nuclear and space arms talks between the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics which opened in Geneva last week.

As to the breakthrough for arms control in Europe, announced in Stockholm, there is quite a deal that I can say about that. Perhaps it would be appropriate if I sought leave to incorporate that in Hansard. It is a significant breakthrough and there is a lot of detail which I think the Senate would be interested in. I seek leave accordingly.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
STOCKHOLM CONFERENCE ON DISARMAMENT IN EUROPE (CDE)

The first phase of the Stockholm Conference concluded during the past few days with agreement on a package of measures concerning advance notice of certain military activities in Europe. The objective of these measures is to introduce a greater element of openness into European military activity particularly military exercises thereby contributing to the prevention of misunderstandings about military movements and to a reduction in tensions.

2. The measures agreed upon include compulsory notification 42 days in advance of military exercises involving at least 13,000 troops or at least 300 battle tanks. Amphibious or parachute drop activities involving at least 3,000 troops are also subject to prior notification. In addition all CDE participants will have the opportunity to observe military exercises involving at least 17,000 troops, or in the case of amphibious/parachute drop activities, at least 5,000 troops. A potentially significant development is the acceptance of compulsory on site inspections from the air or ground (or both) to verify compliance with the information exchange measures.

3. Confidence building measures of this sort are one step removed from disarmament since they do not necessarily involve the reduction of military arsenals. However, the results of this first phase of the Stockholm conference will be assessed at the Conference on Security and Co-operation in Europe (CSCE) review meeting which commences in Vienna on 4 November. The Vienna meeting will decide whether sufficient progress has been made for the CDE to proceed to its second phase when actual disarmament measures will be discussed.

4. Although Australia is not a participant in the CDE it has followed the conference closely. The Government welcomes the agreement which has been reached at Stockholm. Australia takes the view that greater openness on military activities is essential if meaningful progress is to take place on disarmament and arms control.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can it also be tabled?

—Yes, the honourable senator can have it straightaway. As to President Reagan's speech to the United Nations General Assembly, I can say this: In his recent address to the United Nations General Assembly, President Reagan has given details of his most recent arms control proposal to General Secretary Gorbachev. Mr Reagan has indicated a willingness to agree not to deploy any strategic defensive system which might be generated as a result of the research into strategic defences being conducted by both sides for the next seven years or so if the United States and the Soviet Union could reach common ground on reducing strategic defensive forces. This offer is apparently in response to an earlier proposal by Mr Gorbachev that both sides should proclaim their commitment not to withdraw from the anti-ballistic missiles treaty for the next 15 to 20 years.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, I can say, welcomes these developments as an indication that the two sides now appear to be, at long last, engaged in a process of substantive negotiations on these important issues. We have long seen a need for not only the Soviet Union but also the United States to come to agreement on the issue of research into strategic defences and for assurances against sudden breakout or withdrawal from the ABM treaty. Such understandings would, in the Government's view, reduce the likelihood of an arms race in outer space and enhance prospects for concluding an agreement or agreements to reduce offensive nuclear weapons radically.

As to the final point about Australia and Australian initiatives and a role for them in these matters, we will certainly continue to exercise our influence to the utmost in support of international disarmament. The principal focus of our efforts will remain the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva where our principal objectives will be, firstly, the achievement of a comprehensive test ban treaty; secondly, the conclusion of a convention on chemical weapons; and thirdly, the securing of agreement on measures to prevent an arms race in outer space. I should also perhaps refer in this respect to what Mr Hawke said in the House of Representatives on 24 September, addressing a question put to him at Question Time on those matters. I thank the honourable senator for his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the recent promise of the Leader of the Opposition to abolish the fringe benefits tax `lock, stock and barrel', to quote his words, if or when he comes to power. I ask the Minister whether the Government has evaluated the cost to revenue if that promise were to be kept and what the evaluation shows.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The estimated revenue for this financial year from the fringe benefits tax is $325m and the estimate for the next year, with full year effect, is $575m. The cost of abolishing the tax, however, would ultimately be a good deal more than that because if Mr Howard were to implement the undertaking he gave yesterday and abolish the fringe benefits tax there would be a stampede into the conversion of income from income in cash to income in kind. In other words, the taxation system would again haemorrhage with loss of revenue and the tax base would be whittled away, probably to about half the size it now is, if that disastrous undertaking of the Leader of the Opposition were actually put into place.

ANSWER.PARA: There are other estimates, explicit and implicit, of the present revenue yield of the fringe benefits tax. For example, I referred to one the other day in the advertisement sponsored by Mr Hay, Mr Ansett and Mr McLachlan, which implicitly stated that $2 billion would be collected from small business alone. I would not expect that small business would be paying as much fringe benefits tax as big business. That, of course, is a patently false estimate, put in by three completely unscrupulous people in an attempt to enlist recruits for their cause.

It is worthy of note that two possible interpretations could be put on Mr Howard's promise that the fringe benefits tax would be abolished. One is that he would actually enforce effectively section 26(e) of the existing Income Tax Assessment Act. That is something he failed to do when he was Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commissioner enforces the law.

—So I do not believe that there would be any more chance of his doing it this year. I gather that Senator Messner wants section 26(e) applied. That then raises the question that if it is Mr Howard's policy to go down the section 26(e) route, for what period will he apply section 26(e)? Will it be applied retrospectively? That is a question which I hope Senator Messner will answer for us one day. Is Mr Howard proposing, in the unlikely event of his being in government, to enforce section 26(e) and to do it retrospectively? If that were to be the case, for how long would the application or the enforcement of section 26(e) be retrospective? That is one possibility.

ANSWER.PARA: It should also be noted that Mr Howard, in making the statement he made yesterday, repudiated what his shadow Treasurer had said at the National Press Club on 20 August and what he himself said as recently as 30 July-that is, that fringe benefits would be taxed but would be taxed in another way, again implying section 26(e). He is also in direct conflict with the Leader of the National Party of Australia who I am informed said today on the front steps of Parliament House:
26(e) will remain and there has never been any suggestion that it will go.
He was asked:
Should any fringe benefits be taxed?
He replied:
Well there is already an application of some fringe benefits tax by the Tax Commissioner under 26(e). That is the system that has continued and we have not recommended any change to that.

I can only say to Senator Coleman that I do not know what final conclusions one should arrive at after surveying that array of inconsistent and contradictory evidence. The conclusion that I think is the most likely is that Mr Howard has repudiated what he was saying. He has also repudiated what his shadow Treasurer said. The reason that he has done that is that he has buckled under to Andrew Hay's ultimatum that fringe benefits cannot be taxed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I ask His Excellency whether in fact--

—I assume Senator Puplick's appellation for me means that he wants me to be Governor-General. I will quite happily accept that position.

—The honourable senator could wish better than that for me. No, I have not had my attention drawn to the resignation of the gentleman concerned. —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has his attention been drawn to the address given by Professor W. D. Borrie, a well-known demographer, to a seminar in Canberra this week on population in Australia? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the statement of Professor Borrie that, in terms of population, Australia is living on borrowed time? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to Professor Borrie's statement that if society is to survive, the ultimate biological and social aim must surely be at least generation replacement? He said that the present generation of parents has a family the average size of which is likely to be the lowest on record and well below replacement levels. My question is: What will the Government do about that? Are its economic and taxation policies, which discriminate against families, consistent with the survival of society?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do find difficult the question: `What will the Government do about that?'.
—We are all getting a bit old.

—Senator Grimes can speak for himself; I am answering this question. I have had my attention drawn to the address by Professor Borrie. I had it drawn to my attention by Senator Harradine, who asked a question or made a comment about it in the Senate yesterday. But I have not seen what Professor Borrie said and I just accept the summation of Professor Borrie's address contained in Senator Harradine's question. I do not believe that tremendous weight can be attached to the sorts of economic factors that Senator Harradine suggests as dictating population or family behaviour in terms of desired numbers of children and so on. Of course, they must have some influence. But, if that were true, in countries of very poor economic circumstances the top priority would be to limit families; that has not been so.

ANSWER.PARA: The point I am simply trying to make is that a whole range of issues-cultural, social, political and economic-must go into the decision as to whether people want large or small families. Certainly, when larger families existed in Australia, the economic circumstances were not necessarily better for the majority of people than they are now. Having said all that, I do not know what the Government will do about this. I would like to say that I will refer the question to the appropriate Minister, but I do not think we have one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In fairness to the Minister and to Professor Borrie, because Professor Borrie did advert to the widespread use of contraceptives and to sterilisation, my further question is: Will this have an impact on the Government's family planning policies?
—I do not know. I do not think so. I will ask the Minister for Health about that.

—Is the Minister for Education aware that hundreds of secondary students come to Australia every year under a variety of short term exchange schemes organised by individual schools, school systems and non-government agencies, such as Rotary International, the Red Cross Society, the Young Men's Christian Association and Youth for Understanding? Will such students attending Australian schools be subject to the proposed $300 charge on overseas secondary students, no matter what the length of stay or under what scheme they come to this country? If that is the case, how does the Government propose to overcome the loss of opportunities to build important cultural bonds between young people from around the world-bonds which promote the strongest ties between countries and which will undoubtedly be harmed by this extraordinary fee impost?

—The decision to make a $300 charge for secondary students coming from overseas to undertake full time study here was based on the assumption that those students were coming to pursue full secondary education here analogous to the way in which overseas students pursue undergraduate or postgraduate studies. Certainly, there was no intention to discourage student exchanges of the kind to which Senator Macklin referred. Indeed, the Government supports those and believes that they serve all kinds of useful purposes for the young people concerned and for their societies. It was certainly not our intention to impose the fee on other than students who come here to pursue their secondary education in a normal formal sense. However, I will have to explore further the way in which the Bill is being drafted to ensure that that policy intention is maintained.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 18 September entitled `New right fires a salvo at Howard'? Is the Minister aware that in that article Mr Hay demanded that Mr Howard support the new or extreme Right's proposal for a maximum rate of tax of 30 per cent or face voter desertion at the next election? I ask: Has the Government considered the implications of a flat rate of tax? If so, what are the implications in this proposed policy for the vast majority of pay as you earn taxpayers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indeed aware of the ultimatum which one of the mouthpieces for the extreme Right, Mr Hay, delivered in that article on 18 September. He said, among other things:

ANSWER.PARA: I and others have made it clear to Mr Howard that if he does not bite the bullet the conservative ground will be populated by other than the Liberal Party.

The demand was for a maximum tax rate of 30 per cent. As I mentioned in answer to another question, there is already very disturbing evidence that one of Mr Hay's other ultimatums has been accepted by the present weak Leader of the Liberal Party. These demands for a flat tax and a tax of 30 per cent maximum and all that sort of thing lead me to make a couple of other comments. First, if flat tax were to be introduced and to raise the same amount of revenue as existing taxation does, everybody on a taxable income of less than about $26,000 a year would be paying more tax than at present. It should be noted that the great majority of the farmers that Ian McLachlan purports to represent have taxable incomes, according to the National Farmers Federation, of about $5,000 or $6,000, or, according to somewhat more reliable sources, such as the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, incomes of around $10,000; so the overwhelming majority of farmers would be worse off.

This sudden fascination with a maximum tax rate of 28 per cent appears to have been prompted by recent tax changes in the United States which have been either grossly misunderstood or misrepresented. This matter is analysed in an excellent article in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald by Ross Gittins. I would like to give all the details in that article, but I shall select a few of the highlights. The 28 per cent maximum rate, which is supposed to come in in the United States, does not take account of the 7.2 per cent social security levy which applies to incomes up to $62,000. It does not take account of the State income taxes which are levied in the United States. In two of the largest States, State income tax is 10 per cent. If one adds that figure, one has already got up to a 45 per cent maximum rate.

Moreover-and I am sure that if this were known Mr Hay's fascination with the American system and his support for that system would be much less popular among the constituency that he apparently represents-under that system there is no provision for averaging taxation, even for farmers. Perhaps most important of all, a capital gains tax at a rate of 33 per cent is applied on nominal gains, without any allowance for inflation. As to household income, if there are two people in a household their income is aggregated for taxation purposes. In other words, virtually all of the second income, assuming that the incomes are around the average, will be taxed at the maximum marginal rate, and so on and so forth. Above all, over the next five years this tax reform package which the United States Administration is bringing in will collect an additional $194 billion in taxes from business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did the Minister for Veterans' Affairs authorise the Federal Police and a Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs handwriting expert to examine a media release and attachment issued by the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Tim Fischer, on 22 May last? Is it a fact that the investigation took place without reference to or without any attempt to seek handwriting examples from Mr Fischer, who has stated categorically in another place that the writing is his own? Will the Minister table the full report of the handwriting expert from the Immigration Department, Mr P. D. Westwood?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Towards the end of May the Department of Veterans' Affairs organised a function at the Australian War Memorial for the purpose of proclaiming the Veterans' Entitlements Act. While the function was taking place, the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs attacked me and the function, claiming that it was a misuse of the Australian War Memorial to use it for that purpose. He ignored the fact that Sir William Keys, Dame Beryl Beaurepaire, the Secretary to the Department of Veterans' Affairs and I were the speakers and the function was not at all political. It was an attempt to explain to the new recipients under the Veterans' Entitlements Act the benefits that were to be conferred on them.

ANSWER.PARA: The shadow Minister, in his Press statement, said that he had received certain documents from senior levels of the Australian War Memorial. I drew the attention of the Chairperson of the Australian War Memorial to the shadow Minister's Press release but, as she was going on holiday to a Pacific island, I called in the Director of the Memorial to give an explanation. I asked him for the facts and whether he was in any way involved in the preparation of the Press release relating to the function. The Press release came from a staff bulletin within the Australian War Memorial and distributed in the day prior to the holding of the function.

The Director informed me that he was in no way responsible for the use of the words that the function was being held at the direction of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. At that time I had in front of me a copy of the minute that had been approved by the Director, with the Director's own handwriting on it, in which he had inserted on the draft Press statement the words `as a result of a ministerial direction'.

As it turned out, he had lied to me about that document. Naturally I took certain steps to check on the veracity or otherwise of the words that were written on the staff bulletin and the minute associated with it. That was the catalyst which brought to a head a number of matters which had been causing me concern over a period and brought to my attention the need to examine more carefully the administrative deficiencies and problems associated with the War Memorial.

It is true that the Director sent me a letter dated the following day in which he admitted that he had misled me; that he had checked the files and found that he had placed on the draft minute the words `as a result of a ministerial direction'. He apologised to me.

I find it indefensible that if the Director had misled me-and he admitted that he had-he did not take steps that evening or the following day, when I was still in Canberra, to rectify the position. It was not until four days after my meeting with the Director at which I sought an explanation that my office and the office of the Chairman of the Repatriation Commission, Mr Volker, received a copy of the Director's retraction of the evidence that he had placed before me.

Naturally I was entitled to-and promptly did-invoke the support of the Australian Federal Police in respect of these matters in view of the Director's earlier denial. I also brought the matter to the attention of a handwriting expert in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

—I am not prepared to table any documents at this stage or until the investigation has been completed.
