DEBATE.TITLE: NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE: SENATE INFORMATION SYSTEMS DEVELOPMENTS

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the Senate that I have had a statement prepared on Senate information systems in the new Parliament House. Copies of the statement have been distributed in the chamber. With the agreement of the Senate I propose to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I inform the Senate that, in accordance with the Department of the Senate's information systems strategic plan as approved by the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, the Department issued on 23 June 1986 a request for tender for the supply, installation and maintenance of computer-based systems for the Senate in the new Parliament House.

The aim of the process is the selection and implementation of a Senate network in the new Parliament House. This network will eventually provide integrated communications, word processing, information storage and retrieval, data processing, electronic publishing and printing services for senators and the Department. Equipment currently being issued to senators in Parliament House will be able to use the services available on the network.

Because of the direction issued by Madam Speaker, her predecessor and myself that compatibility of systems across parliamentary departments and between senators' and members' equipment be ensured, each parliamentary department has been invited to incorporate within the tender process its requirements for office automation and communications facilities and to participate in the subsequent evaluation of tender responses. These invitations have been accepted and the result will be a single office automation environment for the whole of the Parliament. This result will ensure maximum compatibility between all Parliament House systems.

The request for tender is based on networking and information storage and retrieval studies which have taken place over many years. The document incorporates the recommendations of the joint working group which determined the cabling direction for the new Parliament House in 1984. That working group comprised the five parliamentary departments, the Parliament House Construction Authority, the secretariat of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House and the network engineering consultants Crooks, Michell, Peacock and Stewart.

The document also incorporates the results of a two-year pilot study of free text information storage and retrieval techniques conducted jointly by the five parliamentary departments through their information systems interdepartmental committee.

During the past 12 months, the Department of the Senate has undertaken exhaustive studies not only to determine the user requirements which necessarily determine the substance of the request for tender, but also to equip itself with as much knowledge as would ensure that these requirements would be comprehensively and realistically translated and incorporated into tender specifications for hardware, software, training, maintenance and support services.

To compile this information the Department conducted extensive surveys of senators, their staffs, and departmental officers. In addition, independent assessments of requirements were made by Coopers and Lybrand, W. D. Scott and Housley Communications, consultants. The Housley Communications consultants work covered the communications requirements of all parliamentary departments. The major requirements of senators and members include the ability to communicate effectively with their electorate offices.

Also during this period, two departmental officers travelled overseas to study information systems developments relevant to Parliament's requirements. They visited parliamentary sites where relevant information systems have been implemented, interviewed incumbent equipment and software suppliers and, in particular, assessed the networking and information storage and retrieval standards which the Parliament has adopted.

Last but by no means least, I inform the Senate that the request for tender issued by the Department offers Australian industry real opportunities. The document encourages part tenders from Australian companies in their own right and the complex task of marrying Australian components into the overall solution will not be evaded. Departmental officers are seeking high Australia-content equipment from Australian companies, and suppliers tendering in respect of the new Parliament House are aware of this approach. The Department has been in continuing contact with the Australian Computer Equipment Manufacturers Association and the Australian Software Industry Association and has extended the closing date of the tender at their request.

I believe that the path followed by the Department of the Senate with the full co-operation of the other parliamentary departments will ensure a most cost effective implementation of information systems for the Senate in the new building whilst at the same time maximising the opportunity for Australian industry involvement.

The statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is in fact a statement of good intentions. I can only say that there is a lot of truth in the old saying that the road to hell is paved with good intentions. There is nothing in this statement which indicates that the Government is taking clear and firm action in the direction that was predicted by the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister, in his address to the nation on 11 June, said:
. . . under successive Governments, including my own, the federal public service has continued, inexorably, to grow in numbers.

He said that the Government would take steps to halt this expansion to produce a leaner, more efficient Service. He said that there `will be a streamlining and rationalisation of some existing functions and agencies'. There is nothing in this statement which suggests a streamlining and rationalisation of existing functions and agencies-far from it. So the Prime Minister has, in fact, not lived up to his words; there is no streamlining and rationalisation of existing functions and agencies brought forward in this statement. The statement has been brought down after a period of great growth in the Commonwealth Public Service. There has been record growth in the Public Service under the present Administration. It has averaged 3.5 per cent per annum, with just under 15,000 new positions from when the Government came into office up to 1985-86. A general saving of 0.5 per cent in average staffing levels is something which we might welcome. But when one reads the next paragraph of the statement one finds that the actual result this year will be to have a rise in the size of the Public Service, not a fall. The statement goes on to say:

In this statement the Government talks about a cut in the Public Service and a decline of 2,000 in the number of public servants, but in fact is budgeting for, and tells us in this statement that there will be, a rise in the number of public servants. So, in fact, all this statement represents is an attempt to prune back some of the growth which would otherwise have been projected. It really is a farce. One is reminded of the words which were attributed to St Augustine: `Lord, make me pure, but not yet'. We have a promise for the pruning of the Public Service and, at the same time, a growth in the Public Service. An examination of this statement makes it quite clear that what we have here is simply a series of measures which the Government is proposing and which it says will ultimately lead to the Public Service operating in a more efficient way. That is quite clear, again on the face of the document itself. On page 12 of the statement which has been tabled it is said that:
Many of the measures I have referred to will require legislation, and others will require detailed guidelines and procedures.
The statement goes on to say:
In those cases requiring only administrative action, I have asked the Public Service Board to proceed as a matter of urgency.

The sad fact of the matter is that all of this is projected action. None of it involves the Government coming in and saying: `As a result of this decision we are able to say that there will be a reduction in the need for public servants. There is a removal of a certain number of places which have to be funded by the taxpayer'. The whole summary of the statement makes that quite clear. The whole thing is a statement of intentions for the future, and the record of this Government is one which gives one very little cause for confidence that the good intentions will be followed. If we look, for example, at the promises about efficiency dividends, we see that we have various undertakings being given by the Government that it will insist on departments making efficiency improvements; it will entitle departments to keep some of the benefits of those improvements to further improve the operation of departments, but that it will expect the taxpayer to get some reduced burden because of improved efficiency. All that I can say is that I think those words will provide a very good brief for future Estimates committees to pursue the Government to ensure that some action has been taken, because I think that, on the face of it, it is extremely unlikely that action will be taken in the form which has been predicted.

Looking at the whole series of statements which have been made on page 2 of the statement, such as the future establishment of an efficiency scrutiny unit and the fact that in future departments will be required to cut their administrative expenses in each year, I can only say again that there is nothing in the Government's record which would give anyone grounds for hope. The Prime Minister's statement that the Government would be doing something about Public Service matters was made in June. Since then the Government has brought down its Budget and we find in that Budget-I refer only to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, which is the Department that I have most carefully scrutinised-that the overall administrative expenses of that department, the Department which is presided over by Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, are up by 19.6 per cent. It is very impressive to be told by the Government that it is about to reduce administrative expenses and that it is about to do something about this terrifically increased administrative burden, but we find that in the Department of the Leader of the Government administrative expenses in one year have gone up by nearly 20 per cent. The inflation factor-the factor which the Government allowed to simply have constant administrative costs-was 6.9 per cent. So we have here a real growth of something like 13 per cent in that Department alone.

How is it, when these reforms were promised in June and the Budget was brought down in August, and this statement is produced in September, that the Government can come into this place and, with a straight face, suggest that it will have this wonderful approach to administrative expenses when in the Department of the Leader of the Government in the Senate we find that the administrative expenses have gone up by 19.6 per cent? In the Australian Customs Service, which is another part of the Minister's responsibilities, we find administrative costs up by 12.8 per cent-once again, something like a 6 per cent increase over and above the constant level that one would expect if the Government were even trying to prevent administrative expansion.

So the Opposition is not vaguely impressed by the Government's statement. It is too vague. It totally fails to live up to the Prime Minister's promise that there would be a streamlining and rationalisation of functions and agencies. There is nothing in this tabled statement which refers to the rationalisation of functions and agencies; there is no more than a statement of broad intentions.

Mr President, I pose the question for you, as somebody who had the job of working with a Senate committee on the Estimates for the Parliament, and the Senate in particular, whether you were given the room to expand your administrative costs by 19.6 per cent. I just wonder what sorts of rules the Government has because my recollection of the efforts of the Senate to deal with its own expenditure is that we conscientiously tried to remain within guidelines which prevented any growth in expenditure, yet we find a department being entitled to have a 19.6 per cent increase in administrative expenses. I put that, Mr President, as the context within which we respond with considerable cynicism to the statements of intention which are contained in this paper, because the Government's record is that it has produced nearly 15,000 extra Public Service positions over its first three years. The Government's record is that it has introduced record expenditure and record taxation. The Government's record is-I think this will be found in other areas of the Estimates-that the benefits which have flowed through to the people of Australia have been watched with some care by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), but the administrative expenses of departments have been allowed to grow in a way which is out of line with the sorts of Budget guidelines which I certainly thought this Government was imposing.

I think that this is part of the Government's attempt to use the rhetoric which fits the mood of the moment. There is no sign, however, that the Government intends to bite the bullet. We find nothing in this statement, for example, about the reintroduction of the `no work as directed no pay' provision. I remind the Senate that earlier this year public servants held nearly $1 billion of taxpayers money out of the banking system at very great cost to the taxpayers and the Commonwealth and the probable cost of increased interest rates-a situation which is quite intolerable. The Government has left itself without the reasonable weapons that a government requires to deal with that sort of anti-public interest behaviour by public servants. I think in that circumstance we actually had the Government going off to the arbitration authorities to seek the temporary reintroduction of a `no work as directed no pay' provision within the award. The failure of the Government to come to grips with that most elementary requirement of public servants, namely, that they should do the work for which they are employed and not pick and choose and decide that in the pursuit of their own industrial objectives they will refuse to obey the lawful commands of their employers, shows how threadbare is the Government's approach to this problem.

It is worth pondering that dispute of early this year. I know that many honourable senators opposite have had long industrial experience and they would have a great attachment to the importance of access to arbitration in situations of dispute. I remind them of the activities of some public servants who have refused to accept the decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission; they have engaged in strike activity in contravention of their access to that machinery, and the Government has left itself without weapons to look after the public interest in that circumstance in which the rules are being flouted by the people who are paid at public expense to look after the concerns and interests of the people of Australia.

This is an important statement. Many of the statements of intention are consistent with the views that have been urged by the Opposition upon the Government. We welcome the extent to which the Government has embraced objectives which we think are in the national interest, as we have defined them. It is a matter of deep disappointment to the Opposition that there is so little substance in this statement. Nothing in it says to the people of Australia or this chamber `Here are the things which the Government is definitely doing and which will do something now about inefficiency, overmanning and excesses' which the statement concedes exist. It is, therefore, a very disappointing statement, and I look forward to the opportunity to debate it more fully at some future time. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Despite the debacle that went on a little while ago and the fact that, as Senator Chaney indicated, this is more a statement of intention from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) than an outline of a program of works or legislation, the Australian Democrats welcome the statement, as indeed we would welcome any measures that are intended to improve the efficiency of the Public Service. Unlike the Opposition, however, we are not in favour of doing things such as randomly and unscientifically slashing Public Service ceiling levels or staff numbers generally; nor do we favour the theory of allegedly increasing efficiency in the public sector by privatising bodies such as Australia Post and Telecom Australia. That sort of privatisation policy really amounts to selling off the profitable parts of public utilities, leaving the Government to continue to provide to the public those services from which the private sector cannot wring a profit and which essentially must therefore have their costs borne by the public purse, that is, Consolidated Revenue or taxpayers' contributions. Telephone and postal services to areas which are isolated and which generally are represented by members of the National Party of Australia, for example, would fall into that sort of category.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, we welcome the measures, such as they are, that are contained in the statement that was tabled earlier this afternoon. Indeed, we would have welcomed them a decade ago because these measures are not only necessary but also long overdue. On page 4 of the statement we are informed:

. . . to encourage more economical and efficient use of funds provided to them, Departments and agencies will be permitted, in effect, to carry over unused administrative funds from one year to the next, subject to a limit on the amount of carryover. This will remove the incentive to try to spend all remaining funds at the end of each financial year, and should result in a more rational and efficient allocation of resources. Departments and agencies also will be given greater freedom to move funds between their Salaries and Administrative Expenses votes, where this would lead to greater efficiency.

We would certainly applaud that. There has been no greater absurdity, I would suggest, in the funding of departments than the requirement that all funds be expended prior to the end of the financial year or face forfeiture. I recall raising a somewhat similar matter in this place in 1978, in the days when Federal funding to the Department of Education was done on an annual basis and we saw spending splurges at the end of each year by schools as they acted, sometimes with no rationality at all, to spend the money that had been allocated to them because, if they did not, the allocation for the following year would not be as large. There was no capacity for them to carry over money, to use it efficiently or even particularly effectively.

It is worth noting that the Government is flagging the fact that it will take a much more rational attitude to the sorts of funding of departments that we have seen in the past. It is also worth noting that, while departments are to be given greater flexibility in the expenditure of their funds, they will also be expected to do better with less. In the words of the Prime Minister, they will have to work harder, work smarter and give more value for money. That again is something that the general public and certainly those in this chamber and another place would welcome. Presumably to encourage this, an efficiency unit is to be established under the direction of Mr David Block, reporting directly to the Prime Minister. It is too early to tell whether all of this is simply another symbolic exercise that has been inadequately thought out and underresourced or whether we can expect the sorts of results that would be equivalent to those that occurred in the United States of America of something like 2.3 per cent annual savings. I hope it is not, as Senator Chaney indicated, just a bit of window dressing from which nothing much will eventuate. Mind you, I would suggest that 2.3 per cent annual savings sounds a fairly major achievement after nine years, at least in the context of other measures outlined in this statement.

On page 5, for example, we are told that departments will be required to reduce their expenditure by one per cent each year in the next three years starting in 1987-88. That is three times the United Kingdom rate. Setting an arbitrary figure of one per cent savings per year may be good for the deficit-I am sure that is the main rationale behind this-but it is unlikely to be conducive to rational restructuring of the Public Service. We also note that streamlining of the processes of promotion, redeployment and dismissal is long overdue. It is difficult to see, for instance, how anyone could reasonably disagree with the statement that the Prime Minister makes on page 7 of the statement that the Secretary to a department will be able to retire staff from the Service when, after they have been warned and given an opportunity to improve their performance, the Secretary is satisfied that they have remained inefficient. The Public Service, one presumes, ought not to be a haven for people who cannot get work anywhere else; nor should it be perceived as that when I do not believe it is. Any steps that this Government takes to ensure that it does not become such a thing or that public perceptions increase are to be welcomed.

It is to be hoped that the spirit of co-operation which characterised the Australian Council of Trade Unions and employer groups meeting on management practices will extend to reform of the Public Service. The Democrats look forward to an early introduction of the necessary legislative changes in a form that I hope we can support. I repeat that I hope it does not degenerate into what Senator Chaney suggested it could well do; that is, some kind of substitute for action or a bit more of the rhetoric which has come from this Government and which it has been expected could substitute for its doing anything positive to correct the problems that face it.

The Department of Defence proposes to do three things under Project DESINE:
To decentralise its administrative computing systems and to establish a standard computing environment for those systems (the DESINE Strategy);
To implement two major redevelopment projects, called the Supply and the Manpower Systems Redevelopment Projects, under the DESINE Strategy; and
To establish a five year period contract with a prime contractor to establish a standard computing environment and to supply equipment and software for these major redevelopment projects.
The Committee's examination of the Project DESINE proposals has focused on five major issues:
Project cost/benefit justification;
Technical risks;
Australian industry participation;
Proposed method of acquisition; and
Staff resources required.
The Committee's examination of these issues has led it to recommend that a phased implementation and procurement strategy be adopted for Project DESINE.

The Committee concludes that, given the size, complexity and duration of the DESINE redevelopment projects, the only satisfactory approach is to plan, cost/benefit justify, obtain funding approval and implement each sub- project of the DESINE projects in turn. The initiation of each sub-project should be considered in the light of a review of the preceding sub-projects. This should allow the effective monitoring of both the expenditure on, and the benefits resulting from, these projects.
The Committee therefore recommends that:

The Department of Defence not procure implementation quantities of equipment for each major sub-project of the Supply and Manpower Systems Redevelopment Projects or any other projects to be implemented under Project DESINE until:
The planning, systems definitions and cost-benefit studies necessary to define and justify these sub-projects, have been completed;
The Secretary of the Department of Defence has endorsed each of these sub-projects in turn and the funds necessary to implement them; and
A submission dealing with these sub- projects has been made to the Committee under its standing reference to examine and report on ADP acquisition proposals over $5 million.
The first of these sub-projects is likely to be the Depot/Base sub-project of the Supply Systems Redevelopment Project which will involve approximately $30 million capital expenditure.
The Committee also recommends that:

The Department of Defence provide an annual progress report to the Department of Finance and this Committee which summarises progress to date on Project DESINE and its component projects against agreed plans. This report will detail:
The benefits achieved in comparison with those initially asserted at the time of project approval;
the costs incurred to date in comparison with those initially asserted;
the degree of Australian industry participation achieved; and
the proposed expenditure for DESINE projects for the following financial year.

The Department of Defence also intends to let a single, five year period contract as part of Project DESINE, for the supply of two things: a `network architecture' which will provide the basis for its computing standards; and subsequently, implementation quantities of equipment and software conforming with those standards.

The Committee is recommending a two-stage tendering process be employed to ensure the supply of a satisfactory `network architecture' and the establishment of satisfactory standard, before large quantities of equipment are purchased. This will minimise the risk of major cost overruns should difficulties be experienced improving the `network architecture' and establishing satisfactory computing standards. A two-stage tendering arrangement will also increase competition in the tendering for these separate supply requirements and will increase the opportunities for Australian firms to participate.

Although a two-stage tendering process may involve some additional administrative costs, it need not cause any delay to the main implementation phase of the Supply and Manpower Systems Redevelopment Projects. The Committee believes that any additional costs and small delays in the early stages of Project DESINE will be more than justified by the reduced risk, greater competition and greater opportunities for Australian industry participation which will result.

The Committee believes that Project DESINE offers a major opportunity for government purchasing to contribute to the development of a technologically advanced, innovative and competitive computing industry in Australia. It has therefore recommended that special measures be taken, above and beyond the application of Australian purchasing preference and offsets policies, to ensure that this opportunity is not missed and that a satisfactory level of Australian industry participation is achieved in the DESINE contracts.
The Committee therefore recommends that:

Part tendering arrangements be adopted in the major implementation phase of Project DESINE to increase the prospects for Australian industry participation in the supply of specific categories of equipment and software;

In addition to the enforcement of the Australian purchasing preference and offsets policies, the level of Australian industry participation be a specific criterion in the evaluation of tenders for the DESINE contracts;

The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services participate in the weighting of this evaluation criterion and review the level of Australian industry participation in the recommended tenders before contracts are let; and
If a satisfactory level of Australian industry participation cannot be agreed at Departmental level, the matter be referred to the responsible Ministers for decision.

The Committee has also reviewed the two other, and quite separate, proposals contained in the Department of Defence's submission to purchase computing equipment for the Office of Defence Production and to establish a period contract for the purchase of small, stand-alone computing systems.

The Committee has given qualified support to the proposed procurement for the Office of Defence Production. It is recommending that the tendering for new equipment for the Office of Defence Production be expedited as quickly as possible. However the Committee is not convinced of the justification for the proposed purchase of a $1.85 million second hand computer to provide interim computing capacity until such time as new equipment is purchased.

The requirement for this interim capacity has arisen because of a two and half year delay in the provision of suitable accommodation for a warehoused computer already owned by the Office and capable of meeting all its interim requirements. The Committee will be investigating further the reasons for this extended delay, in its current inquiry into the Administration of Commonwealth Property Functions.

The Committee believes that the small, stand-alone systems proposal was included in the Defence submission as something of a sop, to compensate for the very limited opportunities offered to Australian firms in the DESINE and Office of Defence Production contracts initially proposed by Defence. However the level of use proposed for this stand-alone, systems contract has not been specified by Defence, and hence the level of benefits to a successful Australian tenderer is also unspecified and uncertain. The Committee is convinced that the alternative arrangements which it has proposed for the DESINE procurements will provide far better prospects for Australian industry participation in the supply of equipment and software to the Department of Defence.

The Committee also notes that there are adequate, alternative means available to the Department to procure small, stand-alone computing systems and that the establishment of a new period contract for the supply of such equipment to the Department of Defence is not justified.

The Committee issued guidelines for submissions under its standing reference, and invited comments from Departments on these, in May 1985. It has to date received no comments and can only assume that Departments consider these guidelines to be satisfactory. The Committee itself has identified some areas of deficiency and of potential improvement in the guidelines. It now intends, with the benefit of its experience of the three inquiries it has now completed under the reference, to issue revised guidelines which will, it hopes, assist departments to prepare better submissions and therefore expedite the process of the Committee's inquiry and report. The Committee continues to welcome any comments that interested departments and agencies may wish to make on the guidelines.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting, I was commending the Government for its safety net legislation with regard to chronically ill users of pharmaceuticals. I point out that, after the twenty-fifth script, further pharmaceuticals will be provided free. Pharmacists will keep records for this purpose, issue entitlement cards, and be appropriately reimbursed by the Government for the administrative work involved. This scheme has been developed with the co-operation and support of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. It is pleasing that government and a professional body can work so successfully together in devising a program which is both mutually satisfactory and to the advantage of the community generally. This is a commendable achievement but, sadly, the exception rather than the rule, as so often relevant associations are not adequately consulted by government about proposed changes.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth major area of change introduced by the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is the abolition of the Commonwealth's isolated patients transport and accommodation assistance scheme and the transfer of funds for this purpose to the States. The Australian Democrats support this move. The IPTAAS program is just the sort of activity for which it is patently bad management to have power vested in a centralised Federal authority rather than in the States and regions where the scheme is used. Democrat policy supports the devolution of power and decentralisation of control in appropriate areas of public activity, and this is one such area. In addition, there have been numerous problems and anomalies within this scheme, several of which have been raised in this place in the past.

It is, of course, critical that governments make provision for the delivery of health care services to those who live in isolated and rural areas. Australians who choose to work and live on the land must not have the standard of their health services and access to services of their choice jeopardised. The Government's proposal to make funds available to the States and Northern Territory to develop and administer their own schemes in place of IPTAAS is to be welcomed. The Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) is well aware of the difficulties that have beset this scheme. State control of this area will provide more flexibility in arrangements, as is appropriate to cater to the different needs of some very different regions in this country. One of the advantages of this is that State health authorities involved in service planning and provision will be in a position to use some of the money made available by the Commonwealth not only to transport patients to hospital and medical services but to service properly regional areas which may have been neglected under the previous IPTAAS arrangements. The States will have considerable flexibility in the schemes they devise. They should have adequate funding to administer what we look forward to as constructive solutions posed by the large scantily serviced distances with which we live in this country.

There are a number of other amendments in the Bill to which I want to draw attention as they warrant some comment. The first is the clarification of secrecy provisions of the Health Insurance Act, which is affected by clause 9. This amendment is the outcome of a review which was requested by the Senate into what have been inadequate protections for the security of information held by the Health Insurance Commission. Only earlier this week we heard of the abuses and wrongful release of information held by the Department of Social Security. These are just the sorts of dangers and infringements on the right to privacy that are some of the considerations which form the basis of the Democrats' opposition to the Government's proposed Australia Card. We welcome clause 9 of the Bill.

I wish also to commend Part IV of the Bill while deploring how long overdue have been improvements in the law in respect of hazardous goods. These amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act relate particularly to the manufacture of biological products and provide for the inspection of manufacturers operations generally. The Secretary to the Department of Health will be empowered to obtain specific information from a manufacturer and to have official tests performed on samples before a batch of a biological product is released for use. This is a step in the right direction but it does not begin to address the extent and complexities of the sorts of problems which were described at length by Senator Vigor in this place on 5 May this year in presenting the second reading speech for the Democrats private member's Hazardous Goods Bill. Extensive negligence, deceit and horrendous chronic injury have been associated with the distribution of a variety of supposedly therapeutic, but actually extremely hazardous, goods in this country. It is outrageous that mistakes and cover-ups like that which saw the widespread introduction of the Dalkon shield into Australia can be repeated today. The Government is moving, but only painfully slowly, to act on problems such as those dealt with by Part IV of the Bill.

I wish to comment briefly on two remaining points in the Bill. Clause 14(1) extends the availability of Medicare benefits to cover the cost of surgically implanted prostheses to those operations performed in free-standing day surgery facilities. We welcome this move because, where procedures can be conducted safely without the necessity for an overnight hospital stay, day surgery has the potential to reduce the expenses associated with hospital care and to reduce the waiting lists for surgical treatment, which are of so much concern to all of us.

Clause 37 amends the National Health Act to remove the references to a Minister of the Crown or a contributor to a health fund which presume that those persons are male. The replacement of these references with language that is not gender specific, but not clumsy or difficult, is welcomed by the Democrats.

In commenting on the amendments proposed by the Opposition I suggest that, although aspects of them are of concern to the Australian Democrats, we are not in a position to support the amendments as they stand. Whilst emphasis is placed in those amendments on the issue of waiting lists, neither the Opposition nor the Government in comments on waiting lists during this debate has recognised a further element in that important issue-the fact that problems with staffing of hospitals are occurring because finally, after generations of expectations, nurses, most of whom happen to be female, have decided that they will not wait any longer. This is a protracted industrial relations problem with which I have considerable empathy. It is unfortunate that neither side of the House has recognised that that is part of the problem with waiting lists.

The issue of blowout of costs related to Medicare is one with which the Democrats have sympathy and on which emphasis is placed in the amendment proposed by the Opposition. However, again, on neither side of the House is there recognition that major reasons for that occur outside the fact that we have a Medicare system. There is not enough support for preventive health measures and community based health services and not enough cracking down on the rip-offs in entrepreneurial medicine. In those areas we need more action and the ability to bring down the costs of health care in this country.

If the Opposition had proposed serious amendments that were less all-encompassing and addressed some of the specifics of the issues, it might have been more likely that we would have considered them seriously. I think it is far more the case, in fact, that what the Opposition has recognised, as we have in this legislation, is that the basis of the legislation relating particularly to hospitals is deregulation. The Opposition, of course, cannot be seen to be opposing deregulation as such and therefore it has put up attachments to the second reading motion which really lack substance and which we will not be supporting.

So, to sum up, while there are a number of valuable changes made by the Bill and by the Government's Budget strategy in the health area, there has not really been any substantial redistribution of resources to the public system, which we would have preferred. There has been some extension of the user-pays principle, which is of concern. There is little done for public hospitals. The policy goals of public health, primary health care and community-based service delivery are maintained or have seen some marginal improvements in their funding, but this is a long way from the significant shift of expenditure to health promotion activity which, as I have said, is called for by the Australian Democrats' health policy. The Budget and this Bill fail to grapple with the incentives to the open-ended demand for servicing which is a fundamental problem with the existing health system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators who have contributed to this debate. Like many debates on health legislation in this place, this debate has tended at times to be more about ideology and prejudice than about the facts. I think that one day, if we ever get the time, we should have a general debate on health which is not hung around the necessity to pass a piece of legislation. Maybe we would get some rational debate if we did that.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I wish to make some general comments. We have heard from Senator Walters and other honourable senators opposite the basic argument that the health system is not good, firstly, because costs are burgeoning-and no one denies that-and, secondly, because there are large waiting lists in public hospitals, which also no one denies. This situation is said to be due, entirely it seems, to the introduction of Medicare. The direct cause is said to be a flood of people from the private hospitals to the public hospitals in this community. That seems to be the basis of the argument, that seems to be the key argument, and it simply is not true. I urge honourable senators, and I urge people in general who are interested in this area, to look at the figures. Certain facts are obvious. The occupancy rate of private hospitals in this country is in fact the same now, more or less, as it was before Medicare was introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is. They cannot get into the public hospitals.

—Senator Walters said that the problem is that there are floods of people from the private hospitals into the public hospitals. I say that is not so. In fact, the private hospitals are doing quite well, thank you very much. There is a considerable increase in many procedures in private hospitals. If one looks at the sales of private hospitals and the applications to build new private hospitals one sees that, in fact, there is every evidence that the private hospitals are doing well, and they will continue to do well after the changes in this legislation have been implemented. As the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) in the other place said, private health funds in this country can use some of their $570m in reserves to cushion the changes introduced by this legislation. The increases in fees are small and there is plenty of scope for the private health system in fact to continue to expand in this country as it has done in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had expanding waiting lists in public hospitals for years. This was happening way before the introduction of Medicare. Unless we look at the multiplicity of causes for this and stop this nonsense of just saying that it is all due to bulk billing and Medicare, we will not get anywhere. We need to look at the vastly increased number of procedures that are being performed, at the extraordinary expense of some of the new technology that is being introduced and at the incredible shortage of nurses in some areas-a shortage which is due not to Medicare but to a multiplicity of factors.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will tell you it is.

—The nurses do not tell us that it is due to Medicare. The nurses shortage in this country preceded Medicare, and Senator Walters knows that. The shortage is to do with the archaic working conditions in some hospitals, the hierarchical nature of the nursing profession, the inadequate wages and, as Senator Walters says, the stresses and strains on people working with new technology and in quite hair-raising situations sometimes, particularly in respect of intensive care. To blame that on the introduction of a universal health insurance scheme is nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: To call our universal health insurance scheme `nationalised medicine' is nonsense. I think we ought to look at what has been happening in the Australian Capital Territory and what is happening in the States. We ought to look at what happens in other countries. We ought to look at why, not in the last three years but in the last 30 or 40 years, compared with other countries, in infant mortality, in longevity and in all the morbidity statistics we have gone from the top and are heading way down to the bottom. We ought to look at why a country such as Sweden has the lowest, or next to the lowest, infant mortality rate in the world, has one of the highest longevity rates in the world and has the best morbidity statistics in the world, despite having the very scheme that Senator Walters says brings doom and destruction on the whole of our system.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have just told us that ours is deteriorating under your system.

—I am telling Senator Walters that ours, as a scheme comparable to that of Sweden, has deteriorated in the last 30 years, not the last three years. If Senator Walters objects to the Swedish-type system, she has to explain to us in this place why patients are better off, why children who are born are better off, why people live longer and why they are better cared for under a system which she says has all the features that we should not have in this country.
—Because they are willing to supply money and you are not.
—Oh, for God's sake! They are willing to pay taxes but the people the honourable senator represents are not.
—They have the highest suicide rate in the world there-the highest admissions to psychiatric hospitals in the world.

—I never thought that I would hear Senator Sheil bring up the old furphy that Sweden has the highest suicide rate in the world. Sweden has the highest reported suicide rate in the world. If Senator Sheil had worked in some countries, as some of us have, where there is a stigma against suicide, he would know that there is a hell of a difference between the reported suicide rate in a country such as Sweden and the suicide rate in a country such as Italy or Ireland, in which apparently hardly anyone commits suicide. Senator Sheil knows why that is so and he knows the pressure that doctors are under in those countries. Senator Sheil apparently objects to the low infant mortality rate and all the efficiencies of a health system such as that in Sweden.

SPEECH.PARA: The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills raised some problems with this legislation. It apparently was under the impression-I suppose this was because of the pressure of work-that, under the changes to section 29A contained in clause 46 of the Bill, the decision of the Secretary not to revoke a notice prohibiting the release of a batch of a sample, not to accept the company's application for release for sale of a batch which has been the subject of a notice, will not be subject to review. In fact, under section 29A it will be subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Clauses 41 and 42, which insert proposed new sections 23DA and 23EA, in fact may give the appearance, if looked at by themselves, that there is no review by the AAT. If we turn then to clause 46, which deals with section 29A, we find that in fact there is provision for a review by the AAT. The provisions ensure that decisions taken by the Secretary that could adversely affect a company's operation are subject to this external review. The requirement merely to provide information or samples is considered not to require review because of the later safeguards. That covers the problems raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. Senator Vigor, who raised this and other matters with the Minister, has had a guarantee from the Minister that this matter will be reviewed and that the legislation will be changed if necessary. I think Senator Vigor will talk about that at the Committee stage.

There are many changes in this legislation. I will not delay the Senate by going through all of them. I repeat that we need a plea for good and sensible debate about where we go with our health and health insurance systems in this country. I do not think many of us want a system like that which exists in the United States where the wealthy can afford health care but all too often those people who are poor get no health care. I certainly do not want, and no one on this side of the Parliament is suggesting that we should have, a system such as exists in the United Kingdom where list systems do not work effectively and where they are inhibited by the refusal of governments to apply sufficient attention to the health insurance system. But the world does not consist of just the United States of America, Australia and the United Kingdom. It consists also of the great social democracies of western Europe, all of which have very highly efficient health systems, the outcomes of which to the citizens and the patients of those countries are demonstrably better than the outcomes to people in other systems such as ours. If we do not judge those countries by the outcomes of those systems for individuals in those countries, and if we consider debating this issue on the basis of ideological prejudice, we will continue to do what we have been doing since I have been in this place, which is to have the same old debate with the same old cliches every time health insurance legislation is debated.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder you are on the wrong track, if you believe that.
—I remind Senator Sheil that between 1975 and 1983, when we had a great and illustrious conservative Government, we had no less than seven health schemes in this country.
—Dismantling Medibank.

—For the information of honourable senators I add that Senator Sheil is on record as wanting to dismantle not only Medibank but just about all the systems of health insurance in this country that care for disadvantaged people. I remember that at one stage he was not too keen on the veterans' affairs system and wanted to abolish that. But I doubt whether he says that publicly very often around election time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to Part IV of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill. The Government is proceeding to extend the range of activities it undertakes to help ensure that the manufacture of therapeutic goods is carried out in ways that protect the safety of the public. This is a step in the right direction, coming as it does after the extra $1.3m was set aside in the 1984-85 Budget for the establishment of a register of medical devices sold in Australia. In December 1985 the Acting Minister for Health wrote to me in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The question of adapting the national register of therapeutic goods to provide a reporting system for defects in or injuries due to medical devices and to provide a hazard alert for devices is under consideration.

Will the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) say how much further the matter has progressed, because this is a serious problem? That recommendation was:
That the issue of a national registration scheme, its resources, staffing and operation be referred to the next Health Ministers conference.
Again, I would like to know what, if anything, has happened about that and what the Commonwealth's attitude to such a reference would be.

I note that that Committee was reasonably satisfied with the evaluation of imported therapeutic products, even though there seems to have been continuing inactivity in relation to the Dalkon shield after the marketer of a rival device wrote to the Minister for Health in 1974 claiming that the shield could well contain copper acetate and therefore would be in the bio-active group of IUDs and so classed as a therapeutic good rather than just a plastic device. Other groups, such as the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, have been a little more sceptical about whether the resources put into evaluation of therapeutic goods from overseas have been adequate. The Minister for Community Services might want to respond by indicating how things have been tightened up since AFCO's 1984 submission which was entitled `Deadly Neglect: Regulating the Manufacture of Therapeutic Goods'. The Victorian Social Development Committee had some much more trenchant remarks to make about the situation where therapeutic goods are made in Australia. It said:

The registration of Australian-produced products is vital and is not currently adequately controlled by the Commonwealth. For this reason, the Committee concludes that the present Australian system is unsatisfactory.

The scope of both these pieces of legislation is very much wider than the Government led the general community to believe. It is not surprising that, in this situation of a great deal of confusion in the public mind, Ministers themselves go astray from time to time. This afternoon in the Senate I sought an answer from the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, and, having some difficulty, he indicated that he would seek an appropriate answer from the Treasurer (Mr Keating). However, he then went on to answer my question. Unfortunately his response was not entirely in line with an answer that was given by the Australian Taxation Office. This is not surprising because there are numerous examples where answers on capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax have varied according to whether they were given by the Australian Taxation Office, the Minister for Finance or the Treasurer himself. Also there are inconsistencies in answers from various officers of the Taxation Office, including its regional offices.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has stressed the exemption of the principal private residence from capital gains tax. We are aware that that exemption is outlined in section 160zzq of the Act. However, there is a minefield of areas where the family home is subject to capital gains tax. I am sure that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), who is at the table, would be aware of cases where this occurs-for example, where an elderly person has to move in with relatives, or where people are posted overseas. This afternoon I sought the Senate's approval to incorporate in Hansard a list of 12 areas where the family home is subject to capital gains tax. Leave was not granted at that time. I again seek the leave of the Minister to have my document incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Tax Task Force Secretary, Mr Peter Reith claims he was told by the Tax Office that if he and his family lived in Canberra because of his Parliamentary commitments and they purchased a home in Melbourne in which they intended in the future to reside then that Melbourne property would, until occupied by them, attract a liability for capital gains tax.

The fact is that under the capital gains tax there are many circumstances in which the family home will be subject to tax. It is no wonder that in private correspondence to his colleagues the Treasurer recently estimated receipts from the CGT at ``ultimately $200-300m''.
Mr Reith said that ``Circumstances where the family home will attract liability or will bear the brunt of the tax are as follows:

(1) The capital gains tax exemption is based on the qualification that the family home be not used for income-producing purposes. If a member of the family pays rent or board, the family home will lose its exemption, either in whole or in part. Similarly, if the family home has a study used for work then a liability may be incurred. Ref: Sub-sec. 21.

(2) The sale or gift of the family garden shed, storeroom or other structure, will be subject to Capital Gains Tax. This includes the case where a father gives his son the portable tool shed from the garden. Ref: Sub-sections 1, 3 and 4.
(3) Capital Gains Tax will apply to a new family home purchased by a young couple whilst still living with their parents before their marriage.

(4) It will also apply to a young couple who are renting and who purchase a block for their family home. The young couple will find that the block is subject to Capital Gains Tax. Ref: Sub-section (5e) and (f). This could occur as follows:

(i) The exemption is only available if upon completion of the new house it is occupied for at least 12 months. If for example the young couple have to move (for work reasons) within 12 months then the exemption is lost.

(ii) The maximum exemption-free time allowed under sub-section 5 (f) is 4 years. If because they are building themselves, or they are not saving fast enough and the time lapse between acquisition and occupation exceeds 4 years, then the young couple will have to pay capital gains tax on a pro rata basis.
(iii) If the block is purchased by the young couple prior to their marriage and if one or both of them are during that time dependent on a parent then for that period the block will not be exempt.

(iv) Additional problems will also arise in situations when either or both of the parties have been previously married and still have an interest in a matrimonial home which may be the subject of a protracted dispute and in which the couple are residing pending construction.

(5) If the family home is on more than 2 hectares, then the excess over 2 hectares is subject to Capital Gains Tax. Many people will be caught up by this provision, particularly in outer metropolitan areas where blocks in excess of 2 hectares are very popular. The Assets Test fiasco showed how difficult questions of valuation become, particularly where stringent town planning controls are in force.

(6) If the family home is in excess of 2 hectares and you allow a neighbour to put in a drain at the back of your property, then you are liable for Capital Gains Tax even though you receive no payment from your neighbour. The creation of de factor or de jure easements is very common and this particular provision will cause many headaches.

(7) Where the family home is on a block less than 2 hectares but which is still big enough to subdivide, then any land subdivided off will be subject to Capital Gains Tax on the whole of the sale value. Ref: Sub-section 4.

(8) To claim the tax exemption for land that is adjacent to the family home even when the home is on less than 2 hectares, the land must be used primarily for private or domestic purposes. If this is not the case the land will be taxable regardless of its size. Ref: Sub-section 3.

(9) The family home of a couple which is a unit or flat in a retirement village may not be exempt from Capital Gains Tax unless the owners have a title, a lease or shares in the titles holding. Ref: Sub-section 2.
Note: This will have wide ramifications, as many retirement villages do not grant titles, leases or shares.

(10) Taxpayers can claim only one property as their principal place of residence, although two dwellings are permissible for up to three months where a taxpayer changes homes. Many thousands of Australians will be caught up in the situation where it takes longer to sell property than they had realised. In this situation, if Labor's high interest rate policy does not ruin families through high-cost bridging finance, then the Capital Gains Tax certainly will. Ref: Sub-section 8.

(11) It is not just the so-called rich who will pay Labor's Capital Gains Tax. For people who rent their family home the new tax has meant increased rent as investors try to recoup the tax. Rent increases in capital cities have ranged up to 23.8% with reported increases of 14.1% in Sydney and 12.9% in Melbourne.

(12) A Capital Gains Tax is payable where the family home is owned by a discretionary trust. The Tax Office has attempted some reassuring noises although the Act is clear. Ref: Sub-section 160zzs and Sub-section 12.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 13 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. Is an Australian citizen, Mr Konrad Kalejs, presently living in the United States of America.
2. Is he being investigated by the Justice Department in relation to his activities as a member of the Latvian Security Police during World War 2.
3. If he is a naturalised Australian and is deported from the United States as a war criminal will he be permitted to return to Australia.

4. In the event that he does so, will the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs give an assurance that the Government will act to ensure that he is required to answer here for those war crimes which may lead the United States to determine that he is not fit to live in that country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. A Mr Konrad Kalejs who is believed to be an Australian citizen is presently in custody in the United States.
2. I am informed that he is being held pending a court hearing into his alleged failure to disclose his Nazi connections on his arrival in the United States in 1959.

3. There is no restriction on the entry of an Australian citizen into Australia. It would be necessary to confirm that, at the time of the proposed re-entry to Australia, the person concerned is an Australian citizen.

4. The Government has appointed Mr A. C.
